"You're late," she said. "School ended at three." "And you took three hours to get home?死 you were with Amara?死 you were doing something you shouldn't?' "I was walking. It's called exercise, Amma. You might have heard of it." She made a sound that wasn't quite a laugh and served me rice without asking if I wanted it, which I didn't, because I wasn't hungry, because I hadn't been hungry since the texts came, but grandmother didn't believe in not being hungry and would keep serving until I ate. Grandfather was already eating, his usual evening position at the far end of the table, saying nothing, watching everything. He'd been doing that since I arrived—like he was waiting for something, or memorising something, or just being quiet because that was who he was. I'd never figured out which. "Your parents called," grandmother said. "Sunday, like always. Your father left a voice message. Three minutes, forty seconds.死 would have sent it to you but you never check your email." "I check my email." "You never check your email.死 you always saying you have notifications turned off,死死, why do you have a phone if you never use it?' "Because you gave it to me and said I had to have one for safety." "And now you're using it to ignore your father." She shook her head, but there was something softer in her voice when she said, "死 misses you, that's all. He doesn't know how to say it." I didn't know how to respond to that, so I ate my rice and didn't say anything, and grandmother didn't push, and grandfather watched us both with that quiet attention he had, and the kitchen window didn't close properly as usual and there was a draught on my neck and somewhere in the house a door creaked open and I thought about three blood emojis at midnight and tried not to think about the photo that had come after. The food was good. It was always good—grandmother was an excellent cook, had been for as long as I could remember, and the flavours were the flavours of my childhood, cumin and coriander and something deeper underneath that I couldn't name but had always associated with home. I ate mechanically, tasting without registering, while the conversation moved around me. "Your grandmother's cousin is visiting next week," grandfather said, his first words since we sat down. "From Leicester." "死 didn't know that," grandmother said. "She called yesterday. You were out." "Where was I?" "At temple." "I was at temple." grandmother's voice did something complicated. "死 didn't know you spoke to her." "We spoke. It's fine." He returned to his rice, the conversation apparently over, and grandmother didn't push it, and I didn't ask questions because asking questions in this house was like throwing stones into deep water—you never heard them hit bottom. We finished eating. I helped clear the plates, which grandmother accepted as my duty even though I was a guest in her house, even though I'd never asked to be here, even though some days I wanted to scream that I didn't belong in this kitchen with its smell of decades of cooking and its window that never closed properly and its grandmother who meant well and never stopped meaning well and never would. I went to my room at eight, claiming homework, and lay on my bed and stared at the ceiling and thought about the texts. At eleven, I was still thinking about it. At midnight, my phone buzzed on the bedside table, and I picked it up before I'd even made a conscious decision to move, and the screen showed a message from the same number, the 020 number, the number that had sent me three blood emojis and then a photo of my room from inside my wardrobe. This time, it was just a single emoji. A door. Or a window. Something that might have been either, rendered badly, looking almost like a mouth open wide. I stared at it. I stared at it for a long time, and nothing else came, and eventually I put the phone down and turned off the light and lay in the dark and waited for the next thing to happen. The house creaked. The pipes groaned. Somewhere in the distance, a siren passed, and another, and the night continued, ordinary and strange, and I didn't sleep, and I didn't sleep, and I didn't sleep. --- The text came just after midnight: 🩸🩸🩸
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter establishes a compelling supernatural mystery with strong character work and atmospheric writing. The author successfully creates an unsettling premise - mysterious blood emoji texts and a photo taken from inside the protagonist's wardrobe - while grounding it in believable domestic realism. The characterization is particularly strong. Priya emerges as a fully realized protagonist with authentic teenage voice and specific details that make her feel real - her cracked phone screen, her mechanical eating, her relationship with sleep and technology. The family dynamics ring true, especially the dinner scene where grandmother's criticism masks concern and grandfather's silence carries weight. The dialogue feels natural and reveals character efficiently. The writing demonstrates good restraint in building tension. Rather than over-explaining the supernatural elements, the author lets them speak for themselves. The blood emojis and wardrobe photo are genuinely unsettling without being melodramatic. The pacing builds effectively from the initial text through the photo revelation to the final door/window emoji. The prose style is clean and controlled, avoiding purple language while maintaining atmospheric detail. Descriptions like "the particular nothing of a line that had been disconnected" and "the house settled into its night sounds" create mood without overwriting. However, there are some weaknesses. The chapter occasionally tells rather than shows - "I didn't believe that" is stated rather than demonstrated through action. Some metaphors feel slightly forced, like "throwing stones into deep water" for asking questions. The ending feels somewhat repetitive with the sleep refrain. The chapter follows its plan well, establishing Priya's world, delivering the inciting incident effectively, and ending with appropriate mystery. It captures the darkly comic British YA tone through Priya's dry observations and family interactions. The supernatural elements feel genuinely mysterious rather than explained away. Overall, this is solid opening chapter writing that establishes character, atmosphere, and mystery effectively while avoiding major pitfalls of amateur supernatural fiction. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 2: Wrong Number I showed Amara at lunch, in the corner of the canteen where the noise was loud enough that no one would overhear us. She took my phone, scrolled through the messages, and her face went through several expressions I couldn't read. "Okay," she said finally. "Okay. This is either really good or really bad." "Those aren't mutually exclusive." "True." She scrolled back to the photo, enlarged it, squinted at the screen. "This is your room. Definitely your room. That's your desk, that's your bed, that's the window with the curtain that never closes properly. Someone took this from inside your wardrobe." "I know." "And they sent it to you. At 2:30 AM." "I know." "And you didn't tell your gran." "Are you insane?" Amara almost smiled. "Fair point. What about your granddad?" "Also no. I barely told you." "I feel honoured." She handed the phone back, her expression shifting to something more serious. "I've been thinking about this since you mentioned it. All through English, all through Maths. I couldn't concentrate. The Hecuba speech completely went over my head." "The whole thing's about grief. You didn't miss much." "My grief is reserved for more pressing matters." She pulled out her own phone, tapped something, showed me her screen. "I did a reverse lookup on the number. Nothing. Pay-as-you-go, unregistered, no registered owner. I tried three different apps. Same result." "So it's untraceable." "Basically. Either our texter is very clever about covering their tracks, or—" She stopped. "Or?" "Or there's nothing to find because the number doesn't really exist." Amara's voice dropped, even though no one was listening. "I mean, London numbers exist, obviously, but this one specifically... I can't find any record of it. No calls made, no texts sent, nothing. It's like it's just... there. Waiting." "That's not comforting." "It wasn't meant to be." She ate a Hula Hoop, thoughtfully. "We could try calling it again." "I did. Multiple times. No answer. Just... silence." "Silence can mean things." "What things?" "I don't know. That's the problem." She looked at me, and for a moment, the performative confidence dropped, and I saw something underneath—stress, exhaustion, the particular weight of someone carrying something they hadn't told me about. "What do you think it is? Honestly. Not what we should think, not what a rational person would think. What do you actually think?" I thought about three blood emojis at midnight. I thought about a photo of my room taken from inside my wardrobe. I thought about the silence on the other end of the line, the breath-or-wind that might or might not have been there. "I think I don't know," I said. "And I think that's what frightens me." --- School ended at three, and we walked home together because Amara's mum was working late and her dad was—who knew, Amara didn't say, and I didn't ask—and my grandmother would expect me home before five anyway. The October air was cold and sharp, the kind of day that felt like it was building toward something, and the bus was late and crowded and smelled like wet coats and someone's lunch, and I stood with my forehead against the window and watched London slide past and thought about phone numbers that didn't exist. At the bus stop near my house, Amara touched my arm. "My parents are separating," she said, not looking at me. "They've been— it's been happening for a while. I didn't tell you because I didn't know how. I didn't want to burden you. But you've been— I know you're going through stuff too. With your parents. And I should have said. I'm sorry I didn't say." I didn't know what to say. Amara and I had been friends for years, through everything, but we'd never been the kind of friends who talked about feelings openly. We'd always communicated through jokes and observations and the kind of understanding that didn't need words. "That's awful," I said, which felt inadequate. "I'm sorry." "Yeah." She shrugged, a gesture that was too casual to be genuine. "It's fine. It's complicated. I don't really want to talk about it." "Okay." "But I wanted you to know. Because you told me about the texts. And I realised I'd been lying to you, in a way. By omission. And that's not— I don't want to be that person." "You aren't." "Maybe." She looked at me, and there was something in her eyes that I didn't usually see—vulnerability, maybe, or the exhaustion of holding something together. "I'll come round this weekend. We can investigate properly. I have research to share." "About ghosts?" "About everything." She smiled, and it was almost her usual smile, but not quite. "I'll text you." She walked off toward her road, and I stood at my gate for a moment, watching her go, and then I let myself into the house. --- The house was empty when I got home. This wasn't unusual—grandmother was often out on Wednesdays, at the temple or the community centre or the shops—but it felt different today. The silence was thicker, the shadows deeper, and the particular creak of the third step seemed louder as I climbed it. I went to my room first. I stood in the doorway, looking at the wardrobe. The door was slightly ajar, the way I'd left it that morning. I crossed the room, pushed it open wider, peered inside. Jackets. Old schoolbags. The accumulated junk of a house that had been lived in for decades. Nothing unusual. Nothing that suggested anyone had been standing there at 2:33 AM, taking a photo of my bed. I closed the wardrobe door. I sat on my bed. I took out my phone and looked at the texts again, as if they'd changed since I'd last looked at them. They hadn't. I spent the afternoon doing homework I couldn't concentrate on, and then I went downstairs and made tea—the way grandfather made it, strong and no sugar—and sat at the kitchen table with my book and tried to read about the Treaty of Versailles, which had never seemed more irrelevant. The kitchen window didn't close properly. It never did. There was a draught that came through the gap and made the room feel colder than it should have been, and grandmother had put a cloth in the gap years ago and it had never made any difference. At some point, I noticed the bathroom door. It was at the end of the hallway, slightly ajar, and I could see through the gap to the mirror above the sink. The mirror was fogged, which was strange because no one had used the bathroom since morning. I watched the fog. It wasn't clearing. It seemed to be... moving, almost, swirling in patterns that didn't match the air currents in the house. I looked away. I read about the Treaty of Versailles. I tried not to think about what I was seeing. When I looked back, the mirror was clear. --- Grandmother came home at six, with vegetables from the market and a plastic bag that crinkled with the sound of imports. She kissed my forehead—something she only did when no one else was watching—and set about making dinner. "You look tired," she said. "Too many screens,死死. Your eyes are red." "I've been reading." "Reading on a screen is still screens." She emptied the bag onto the counter—okra, aubergine, fenugreek leaves, the particular ingredients of a childhood I was slowly growing out of. "Your grandfather will be down soon.死 you finish your homework?" "Most of it." "Finish the rest of it tomorrow. Dinner first. Your mother called." I looked up. "When?" "Just now. She wanted to speak to you, but I said you were out. She'll call again Sunday." grandmother's hands were moving automatically, cleaning the vegetables, trimming the leaves, her voice deceptively casual. "She says Singapore is busy. Your father is working late every night. She is— she is finding it difficult." "Finding what difficult?" "Everything. Being there. Being alone. She didn't say it in those words, but—" grandmother stopped, her hands stilling on the okra. "Sometimes, when people go away, they find that the distance is different than they expected. They think it will be easy. They think they will be fine. And then they are not fine." I didn't know what to say to that. I thought about my mother's voice on Sunday's call, bright and performative, telling me about the flat they were renting and the food they were eating and the colleagues she was getting to know. I thought about the gap between what she was saying and what she might have been feeling. "I'll call her," I said. "Tomorrow." "She'll like that." grandmother resumed her work, her hands moving again. "She misses you. They both do. They just don't know how to say it." Grandfather came down at seven, silent as always, and we ate dinner in the particular rhythm of this household—grandmother commenting on my posture, my eating, my everything; grandfather saying nothing but watching everything; me performing the role of granddaughter I'd been performing for three months now. After dinner, I helped clear the plates, and grandmother said, "No phone at the table. Put it away. Let it charge.死 you staring at it all evening,死死, it's bad for your eyes." I put my phone on the kitchen counter, where it couldn't be seen from the table, where it was supposed to be charging, where I couldn't reach it if a text came through. Grandfather caught my eye across the table. He didn't say anything. He just looked at me, and there was something in his expression that might have been recognition, or might have been warning, and then he looked away, and the moment passed. --- I went to bed at ten, earlier than usual, claiming exhaustion. grandmother approved. "Good," she said. "Growing girls need sleep. No phone in bed." "No phone in bed," I agreed. I lay in the dark, in my father's old bed, in the room that smelled of decades of family, and I listened to the house settling around me. The third step creaked. The pipes groaned. Somewhere below, grandmother was watching television at a volume she thought I couldn't hear. At midnight, I got up. I crept down the hallway in my bare feet, cold on the wooden floor, and I retrieved my phone from the kitchen counter. The screen was dark. No new notifications. I stood there, holding the phone, feeling stupid. What was I expecting? Another text? Another photo? Something that would explain what was happening, or at least confirm that it was real? I was about to go back to bed when I heard it. Footsteps. Not on the stairs—somewhere else. In the hallway above me? In the room at the end of the corridor? The back bedroom. I climbed the stairs slowly, quietly, the way I'd learned to move in this house. The back bedroom door was at the end of the landing, always locked, always had been locked as long as I could remember. grandmother kept the key in her room, or so I assumed. I'd never asked. The door was closed. The light above it was flickering—not the normal flicker of an old bulb, but a pattern, almost deliberate, like something trying to communicate. I knelt. There was a gap under the door, maybe an inch, and I put my eye to it and looked through. The room was dark. But there was something on the other side of the door. A shoe. A woman's shoe, old-fashioned, with a small heel and a strap across the front, pointed toward the door from the other side. As I watched, something moved. A shadow, or a hand, or the suggestion of both, reaching toward the gap under the door. I stumbled backward. My phone buzzed in my hand, and I looked down, and the screen glowed with a new message. From the unknown number. 🩸 followed by something that might have been a door or might have been a window, rendered badly, looking almost like a mouth open wide. I ran. I ran back to my room and locked the door and sat on the bed with my back against the wall and my phone in my hands, and I didn't sleep, and I didn't sleep, and I didn't sleep.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong technical competence and character work while building supernatural tension effectively. The writing follows the established plan closely, developing the mystery through investigation while maintaining the darkly comic British YA tone. The character work is particularly strong. Priya's voice remains consistent - her deadpan observations ("Those aren't mutually exclusive") and internal cataloguing feel authentic to a fourteen-year-old processing extraordinary events through ordinary frameworks. The revelation of Amara's parents' separation adds genuine emotional weight and complexity to their friendship dynamic, avoiding the trap of making supporting characters purely functional. Grandmother's brief appearance maintains her established pattern of expressing love through criticism while hinting at deeper knowledge. The supernatural elements escalate naturally from the previous chapter. The pay-as-you-go phone investigation feels realistic for teenagers, and the progression from mysterious texts to physical manifestations (the fogged mirror, the shoe under the door) builds tension without rushing. The final image of the old-fashioned shoe pointing toward the door is genuinely unsettling and specific. The dialogue feels natural throughout, particularly the lunch conversation between Priya and Amara. Their friendship dynamic comes through clearly - Amara's research-driven approach contrasting with Priya's more cautious nature. The emotional moment where Amara reveals her parents' separation is handled with appropriate awkwardness and restraint. However, some elements feel slightly mechanical. The pacing occasionally prioritizes plot advancement over character development, particularly in the middle section where Priya notices various supernatural phenomena. While these observations serve the story, they sometimes read more like a checklist than organic discovery. The ending, while effective, relies heavily on familiar horror tropes (the gap under the door, the mysterious shoe). The writing maintains good control over tone, balancing the supernatural mystery with realistic teenage concerns. The domestic details (grandmother's vegetables, the Treaty of Versailles homework) ground the fantastic elements effectively. The prose is clean and readable without being overly stylized, though it occasionally lacks the distinctive voice that would elevate it from competent to memorable. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 3: Evidence In daylight, there was no shoe. I went back to the back bedroom door after breakfast, when grandmother was occupied with her temple WhatsApp group and grandfather had gone out to the shops. I knelt on the landing, put my eye to the gap under the door, and saw nothing. Just the darkness of an empty room, and dust, and the particular emptiness of space that hadn't been disturbed in years. I tried the handle, even though I knew it would be locked. It wasn't. It turned in my hand, and for a moment I thought the door might open, but it didn't—it was stuck, swollen with age and paint, refusing to budge even when I put my shoulder against it. I went to school. I sat in lessons. I didn't hear anything. The history teacher talked about the Industrial Revolution, and I thought about the house, and the shoe, and the messages, and I wondered if I was losing my mind or if losing my mind might be a reasonable response to the circumstances. Amara found me at lunch, and I told her about the door, the handle that turned, the shoe that had been there and wasn't there anymore. She listened with the particular intensity she brought to things that interested her, and when I finished, she pulled out her phone and showed me a document she'd been working on. "I made a spreadsheet," she said. "Evidence log. Time stamps, content, observations. I thought we should document properly. In case this escalates." "In case what escalates?" "In case it becomes something we can't handle alone." She scrolled down, showing me the columns she'd created. "We should be systematic. Document everything. Date, time, content, location. The more data we have, the better we can understand what's happening." "That's very organised." "I've had a lot of practice." Her smile flickered, faded, came back. "When things at home are chaotic, I find it helps to impose order elsewhere. It's a coping mechanism. Or a distraction. Probably both." I looked at her, at the dark circles under her eyes, at the way her hands were slightly shaking as she held the phone. I thought about what she'd told me yesterday, about her parents separating, about the weight she was carrying that she hadn't wanted to share. "We should meet after school," I said. "At mine. We can investigate properly." "You don't have to—" "I want to." She nodded, and we didn't say anything more about it, and that was its own kind of communication, and we both understood. --- We started in my room, which felt like the centre of whatever was happening. Amara took photographs of everything—the wardrobe door, the bed, the window with the curtain that never closed properly. She measured things with her phone's measuring app, noted dimensions, drew diagrams in her notebook. "Okay," she said, standing in the centre of the room, surveying her domain. "So. Timeline. First text, midnight. Second text, 2:33 AM, with the photo. Third text, midnight again, with the door emoji. Fourth text, after you saw the shoe, with another blood emoji and another door." "Or window." "Door and window are similar enough that the distinction might not matter. Symbolically, both represent thresholds. Transitions. Passage from one state to another." "That's very symbolic." "I'm a very symbolic person." She was pacing now, walking the perimeter of the room, pausing at intervals to examine the walls. "The question is: why? Why is this happening now? Why to you? Why this house?" "I don't know." "There has to be a trigger. Something that activated this. Did you do anything different before the texts arrived? Touch anything? Say anything? Have any particularly strong emotions?" "I texted my mum. It was Sunday. The regular call." "What did you talk about?" "Nothing. The usual. How things are here. How things are there. When they're coming back." "What did you feel when you talked to them?" I sat on the edge of my bed, thinking about the call. It had been standard, really—three-way video, my parents on a screen that kept buffering, everyone performing contentment that none of us felt. I remembered the particular ache of seeing them in a flat I'd never seen, in a city I'd never visited, in a life that was happening without me. "I felt sad," I said. "I felt sad and angry and like I was being abandoned, even though I know that's not fair. Even though they had to go." "Okay." Amara wrote something in her notebook. "Strong emotion can act as an amplifier. A beacon. If something in this house is sensitive to emotional frequency, your distress might have drawn its attention." "That's very specific." "I read a lot of paranormal forums last night. They have theories." "Do any of them work?" "None that I've seen confirmed. But the theories are... extensive." We worked through the afternoon, Amara documenting, me trying to remember details, the hours passing in a blur of photographs and speculation. At some point, grandmother appeared in the doorway, carrying a tray of tea, and observed our activities with an expression I couldn't read. "Amara is staying for dinner," she said. "死'll make extra. Don't stay up too late, Priya. Growing girls need their sleep." She set down the tea and left, and I noticed she'd moved something on my desk—a small statue of Ganesha that usually faced east—and turned it to face the window instead. --- Tyler wandered in around five, as he often did, the neighbour's child with no sense of other people's business and infinite curiosity about things that didn't concern him. He was seven, knew everything about dinosaurs, and had the particular confidence of someone who had never been told no enough. "What's that?" he asked, pointing at my phone, which was displaying the text messages. "None of your business," I said, but Amara was already showing him. "We're investigating something," she explained. "Strange texts. Do you know anything about it?" Tyler looked at the screen with the serious consideration he probably gave to dinosaur facts. "She keeps texting you," he said. "She wants something." "She?" "The lady. The one in your room." He said it casually, the way he'd say the sky was blue or water was wet. "She stands in corners sometimes. She looks at your phone a lot. I think she's trying to show you something, but she doesn't know how." My stomach dropped. "You can see her?" "She's not very good at being seen." Tyler shrugged. "I can see her when I'm not looking directly at her. It's like... when you look at something too hard, it goes away. That's how it is with her." "What does she look like?" "Old clothes. Like in the films. Long dress. She's pale. And she always points at the door." He mimed the gesture—arm extended, finger directed toward the back bedroom. "Like she's trying to tell you something. But she can't talk. She just points." Amara and I exchanged a look. "Has she said anything to you?" I asked. "Even if you couldn't hear it?" "She makes sounds. Like wind. Or like someone trying to speak with a mouth full of water." Tyler made an effortful noise, a wet approximation of speech. "I don't know what she's saying. She sounds sad. She always sounds sad." I knelt down, bringing myself to his level. "Tyler. Can you tell me anything else about her? Anything that might help us understand?" He thought about it, his face scrunched in concentration. "She was here before. A long time before. Before your grandmother. Before anyone. And someone hurt her. And she can't leave because—" He stopped, struggling for words. "Because she didn't finish. Something. She didn't finish something. And she can't go until she does." "Can you tell me what?" "I don't know. She doesn't show me. She just... waits. And points. And tries to talk." That evening, after Tyler had gone home and Amara had gone home and the house had settled into its night rhythms, I sat with my phone and tried to communicate. I typed messages, deleted them, typed others. What do you want? What do you need? Who are you? Why won't you leave me alone? The messages didn't go anywhere. I couldn't send them to a number that might not exist, to a person who might not be a person, to a presence that might not understand the technology it was trying to use. At 11:47 PM, I gave up. I put my phone on the bedside table, turned off the light, and lay in the dark, waiting for sleep. At 11:58 PM, my phone buzzed. I grabbed it before I realised I was moving. A new message, from the unknown number. A string of emojis, seven of them, that almost formed words but didn't quite. 🩸🚪👤🍵💀🌧️🕰️ I stared at them, trying to decode them. Blood. Door. Person. Tea. Rain. Clock. Death. Or time. Or something else entirely. She was trying to tell me something. She was trying so hard, and she didn't have the words, and all she had were these symbols that meant something to her and nothing to me. I typed a reply. I pressed send before I could stop myself. Who are you? The message went. The three dots appeared—she was typing, or something was typing, or the network was doing something that mimicked typing. And then nothing. The dots disappeared. No reply. I waited. The clock crept past midnight. The house creaked and settled. At some point, I must have fallen asleep, because I woke to morning light through the gap in the curtains, and my phone was dead, and the last message on my screen was the one I'd sent, unanswered. Who are you. The question hung there, unanswered, and I thought about a lady in old clothes who stood in corners and pointed at doors and couldn't finish something she needed to finish, and I wondered if I'd ever know, and I wondered if not knowing was its own kind of answer. --- That day, grandmother made changes. She moved objects in my room—"for better energy flow,死死"—and burned something in the kitchen that smelled sharp and herbal and protective. I watched her touch the doorframe of the back bedroom as she passed, a murmured phrase in Malayalam escaping her lips, and I didn't ask what she was doing, and she didn't offer an explanation. Grandfather watched her from his usual position, silent and observing, and when she was gone, he said quietly: "She knows something.死 has always known something. She just won't say it." "Why not?" "Because saying it makes it real." He looked at me, and his eyes were old and tired and knowing. "Some things, when you name them, they become harder to ignore. Your grandmother has spent sixty years learning not to look. Now you're forcing her to look. She doesn't know how to feel about that." Neither did I. I went to my room and sat on the bed and looked at the wardrobe door, which was slightly ajar, and I thought about what might be standing in the corner when I wasn't looking, and I thought about the messages that almost made sense, and I thought about the question I'd asked and the answer I hadn't received. Some things, maybe, couldn't be answered. Some questions, maybe, were meant to remain open. The phone buzzed. I looked at the screen. A new message, from the unknown number. A single emoji this time. A question mark. Or a hook. Or something else entirely. I didn't reply. I didn't know what to say. I just sat there, holding the phone, waiting for the next thing to happen, and the house settled around me, and the afternoon light fell through the gap in the curtains, and nothing was clear, and everything was strange, and somewhere in the distance, a door creaked open all on its own.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong technical competence and faithful adherence to both the character profiles and chapter plan. The writing maintains the established voice of Priya as narrator, with her characteristic deadpan observations and list-making tendencies coming through naturally. The pacing builds effectively from the mundane (checking the door in daylight) to the supernatural (Tyler's matter-of-fact ghost descriptions) to the climactic communication attempt. The characterization is particularly strong. Priya's internal voice feels authentic to a fourteen-year-old caught between skepticism and growing belief. Amara's research-focused coping mechanism is well-executed, and her underlying distress about her parents' separation adds appropriate depth without overwhelming the ghost plot. Tyler's casual acceptance of the supernatural provides effective contrast and moves the plot forward organically. The grandmother's protective rituals and grandfather's knowing silence maintain their established personalities while advancing the mystery. The supernatural elements are handled with appropriate restraint. The emoji communication attempts feel genuinely eerie rather than silly, and the author resists over-explaining the mechanics. Tyler's description of the ghost as someone who "didn't finish something" provides just enough information to intrigue without resolving the mystery prematurely. However, there are some weaknesses. The dialogue occasionally feels slightly stilted, particularly in the research scenes with Amara where the exposition becomes heavy-handed ("Strong emotion can act as an amplifier. A beacon."). Some of Priya's internal observations veer toward the overly literary for a fourteen-year-old narrator, though this is generally well-controlled. The chapter successfully balances the darkly comic tone called for in the prompt. The humor emerges naturally from character interactions and situations rather than forced jokes, while the supernatural elements maintain genuine unease. The British setting feels authentic without being performative. The ending with the question mark emoji is particularly effective - it suggests the ghost is learning to communicate while maintaining the mystery's momentum. The chapter fulfills its stated purpose of "expanding the mystery through investigation while establishing the house's atmosphere." [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 4: Contact I stayed awake that night. I stayed awake and I watched the corner of my room where Tyler said she stood, and I waited, and eventually, at 2:47 AM, she appeared. Not all at once. It was like watching something come into focus—a shape that wasn't there slowly becoming a shape that was, colours bleeding into clarity, the edges uncertain and wavering. She was young, younger than I'd expected, maybe twenty, maybe twenty-three. She was wearing a dress that belonged to another century, something dark with a high collar and sleeves that came down to her wrists. And she was looking at me, and her expression was desperate and frightened and full of something that might have been hope. I couldn't speak. I lay very still in my bed, the phone clutched in my hand, and I watched her, and she watched me, and the silence stretched between us like a held breath. She moved first. She drifted toward my desk, toward the phone charger, toward the glowing rectangle that was probably the most confusing object in her world. She reached for it, and her hand went through it, and she made a sound—not words, but a kind of frustrated noise, the sound of someone trying to communicate through a language they didn't understand. I sat up. I picked up the phone. I held it toward her, an offering, an attempt at bridging whatever gap existed between us. She looked at the phone. She looked at me. Slowly, carefully, she reached out again, and this time her fingers brushed the screen, and nothing happened—they went through, of course they went through—but something changed in her expression. Understanding, maybe. Or the beginning of understanding. I typed with trembling fingers. I pressed the button to translate my words into speech, because I didn't trust my voice, and the phone said in its flat mechanical voice: "Who are you?" The ghost—she, this she, this woman in the old dress—tilted her head like a dog hearing a sound it doesn't recognise. She leaned closer to the phone, and I saw that her face was thin and pale and marked by something that might have been illness or might have been something else, and she opened her mouth and tried to form words. What came out wasn't words. It was sounds—shapes that might once have been language but had been worn down by however long she'd been like this, caught between presence and absence. I heard wind. I heard breathing. I heard something that might have been "Ed" or might have been "Edith" or might have been nothing at all. I typed again. "Edith?" She lit up. Her whole being seemed to brighten, the edges of her flickering less, and she nodded, or something like a nod, and she made that wind-sound again, and this time I heard it more clearly—not words, exactly, but the shape of words, the ghost of language trying to rebuild itself. "Okay," I said, my voice strange in the dark. "Edith. You're Edith." She nodded again, more definitely this time. And then she pointed at the door. The back bedroom door. The locked door. The door that had a shoe in front of it and a gap underneath and something on the other side that I couldn't see. I typed. "What about the door?" Edith—she was Edith, she had a name now, she was a person, not just a presence—made a sound that was almost a word. She mimed something. Opening. Pushing. A door that had been closed for a long time, that needed to be opened, that she couldn't open herself. "You want me to open it?" She nodded, and her expression shifted to something that might have been gratitude or might have been urgency, and she gestured again, and I understood that she was trying to tell me something else, something about the door, about what was behind it, about why it mattered. I typed another question. "What happened to you, Edith?" And her face changed. The urgency faded. Something else came in its place—grief, maybe, or fear, or the particular weight of a memory that had been buried and was now, slowly, being dug up. She reached for the phone again. Her fingers moved over the screen in a way that suggested she'd watched people do this, had been watching for a long time, trying to understand the magic of the glowing rectangle. She couldn't press the buttons—her fingers went through, always through—but she could move them in the patterns she'd observed, and after a moment, the screen changed. She'd opened my photo gallery. She was scrolling through my pictures, looking for something specific, and when she found it, she stopped. It was a picture of the back bedroom door. I'd taken it weeks ago, before any of this started, just a photograph of the hallway for no reason I could remember. And Edith was looking at it, and her expression was terrible, and she was pointing at something in the picture—at the gap under the door, at the shadow I hadn't noticed, at the suggestion of something that had been there all along. I looked at the photograph. I looked at the door in the photograph. And I understood, or began to understand, that Edith wasn't just haunting this house. Edith had died here. In that room. Behind that door. --- The next nights were a process of learning, slow and painful and occasionally absurd. Edith couldn't remember everything. The centuries—or however long it had been—had worn away at her memories like water wearing away at stone. She remembered her name. She remembered that she'd been happy once, a long time ago, in a different place. She remembered that she'd come to this house to work, to serve, to earn money that she was going to use to escape somewhere better. She didn't remember how she died. She remembered fear. She remembered a man—his face was gone, worn away like the rest, but she remembered his hands, what they'd done, where they'd pushed her. She remembered falling. She remembered the sound of her own body hitting the stairs. She remembered lying at the bottom, unable to move, and someone standing over her, and someone saying words she couldn't hear anymore, and then nothing. Nothing for a very long time. And then, somehow, she was here. Still here. Still in the house where she'd died. Still trying to tell someone what had happened, and no one had listened, and no one had believed her, and she'd been trapped here for— she didn't know how long. Time didn't work the same way anymore. Time was just a thing that happened to other people. I tried to communicate everything I could. I showed her my phone, explained what it was, showed her how to send messages (she couldn't, not really, but she could influence what appeared, sometimes, the emojis rearranging themselves into patterns that meant something to her even if they meant nothing to me). I showed her photographs of the outside world, of cars and buildings and people walking past on the street, and she watched with an expression of wonder and grief that made my chest ache. She asked, in her fragmentary way, about the year. I told her. She made a sound that might have been a laugh or might have been a sob, and she held up her hands—twenty-three, she indicated, I was twenty-three—and then she gestured at herself, at her faded edges, at the way she flickered when the light changed. Twenty-three. She'd been twenty-three when she died. And now she was something else, something that didn't have an age anymore, something that had been waiting for a hundred years or more for someone to see her, to hear her, to understand. --- Amara came round on Saturday, as promised, and we worked through the afternoon, piecing together what I knew. She'd brought her laptop, her notebooks, her entire archive of paranormal research, and we spread everything out on my bed and tried to make sense of it. "Okay," she said, looking at my notes—my scattered observations, my attempts to decode Edith's messages. "So her name is Edith. She was a maid. She died in this house, probably in the back bedroom. Something happened—a man, a fall, a cover-up. She doesn't remember the details because the memories are damaged. She's been here ever since, trying to communicate." "That's what I've got." "And she wants you to open the back bedroom door." "She keeps pointing at it." "Have you tried?" "The handle turns, but the door won't open. It's swollen or stuck or—" I stopped. "Grandmother has the key. Or she knows where it is. She's been avoiding the conversation, but she knows something." Amara was quiet for a moment. "Have you asked her directly?" "I've tried. She deflects. Grandfather says she's always known about this, that she saw things when they first moved in, but she won't talk about it." "That's frustrating." "It's—" I didn't know how to finish the sentence. It's what? Unfair? Scary? Making me feel like I'm going crazy? "It's complicated. She loves me. I know she loves me. But she won't help me with this. She won't even acknowledge that it's real." "Maybe she can't." Amara's voice was gentle. "Maybe acknowledging it would be too much. Maybe she's spent so long not looking that she doesn't know how to start." I thought about grandmother's hands, shaking slightly when I asked about the house. I thought about the way she touched the doorframe of the back bedroom, the murmured words in Malayalam, the protective rituals she thought I didn't notice. "Maybe," I said. "But that doesn't help me right now." We worked in silence for a while longer, Amara cross-referencing her research with my observations, trying to find patterns in what Edith was trying to communicate. The emoji messages, when we looked at them together, seemed less random—🍵🚪👤💀, tea and door and person and death, a story told in fragments that almost made sense. "She was trying to tell you about the man who killed her," Amara said finally. "Or the man who was there when she died. The person who covered it up." "She doesn't remember his name. Or she can't say it." "But she remembers that he mattered. That he was important. That he was connected to this house." "She was pregnant," I said quietly. "She showed me. In one of the photographs. She was pregnant when she died." Amara was silent. The weight of it hung between us—this young woman, killed and forgotten, carrying a child that had never been born, that had died with her or before her or somewhere in the terrible gap between. "We have to help her," Amara said. "Whatever she needs. We have to help her." "I know." That evening, after Amara had gone home and grandmother had served dinner and grandfather had eaten in his usual silence, I tried again. I approached grandmother in the kitchen, where she was washing up, and I said, as calmly as I could: "Amma. The back bedroom. What's in there?" Her hands stilled. Just for a moment, just a fraction of a second, and then she was moving again, rinsing the dishes, her voice artificially light. "Storage,死死. Old things. Why do you ask?" "Because there's something I need to understand. About this house. About what happened here." "Nothing happened here." Her voice was sharper now, the defensiveness bleeding through. "Old houses make sounds,死死.死 are young, you don't know.死 think you know, but you don't." "I know there's a ghost." I said it before I could stop myself, before I could think about whether it was the right thing to say. "I know her name is Edith. I know she died in this house, in that room, and someone covered it up, and she's been trapped here ever since. I need you to tell me the truth." The dish she was holding slipped. It didn't break—there was that much luck, at least—but it clattered in the sink, and grandmother's hands were shaking, and when she turned to face me, her eyes were wet. "You don't know what you're talking about," she said, but her voice wasn't convincing. "死 you hear me?死 don't know anything." "Then tell me. Tell me I'm wrong. Tell me there's no ghost, and I'll believe you. I'll stop asking. I'll never mention it again." She opened her mouth. She closed it. She looked at me, and I saw something in her face that I'd never seen before—not disapproval, not criticism, not the careful love she always expressed through control. Just... sorrow. Deep, old, unprocessed sorrow. "I can't tell you that," she said quietly. "死 can't tell you something I don't believe." "Then tell me what you know." She was quiet for a long moment. The tap dripped. The clock ticked. Somewhere in the house, a door creaked. "I don't know everything," she said finally. "死 know that things happened, a long time ago, before we bought this house.死 know that some people are not... resolved. They stay. They wait.死 know that your grandfather has seen things, things he won't tell me, and I have seen things, things I won't tell him, and we have both learned to look away." She took a breath. "死 know that the back bedroom was sealed, psychologically, when we moved in.死 know that there are things in this house that don't want to be found.死 know that some stories are better left buried." "Is that what you think? That I should leave it buried?" "No." Her voice was barely a whisper. "I think you have already found it. I think she has found you. And I think—" She stopped. She shook her head. "I can't help you with this, Priya.死 wish I could. But I spent sixty years learning not to see, and I don't know how to start seeing now." She dried her hands. She left the kitchen. She didn't look back. I stood there alone, in the kitchen that smelled of decades of cooking, and I thought about what she'd said, and I thought about Edith, and I thought about the door that was locked and the secrets it might contain. --- That night, I stayed awake waiting for Edith. She didn't appear at her usual time. I waited past 2:47, past three, past four, and she didn't come. The corner of my room where she usually stood was empty, and the silence was heavy, and I was beginning to think she wasn't coming when I felt it. Cold. Not the ordinary cold of a London October night. This was different. This was cold that came from inside, from somewhere beneath the floor, from something rising up through the floorboards. I sat up. I looked around. And I saw her—not in her usual corner, but by the door. She was looking at me, and her expression was terrified. She was flickering badly, the edges of her form breaking apart and reforming, and she was pointing at the door, and her lips were moving, and even though I heard nothing, I understood. Someone was coming. Someone who shouldn't be here. The handle of my door turned. The door opened. Grandfather stood in the doorway, his nightclothes rumpled, his eyes not quite focused. He was sleepwalking—I could see that now, see the particular blankness of his face, the way he was here but not really here. He shuffled into the room, his footsteps shuffling on the floorboards, and he moved toward the back bedroom door, and Edith pressed herself against the wall, and I understood that this had happened before. Grandfather reached the door. His hand—his sleeping hand, his not-quite-conscious hand—reached for the handle. And Edith made a sound, a sound that cut through the silence, a sound of pure desperate terror, and I understood: if he opened that door, something terrible would happen. Something that had happened before. Something she was trying to prevent. "Grandfather," I said, and my voice was too loud, too awake, too much. "Grandfather, wake up." He didn't wake. His hand closed on the handle. He began to turn it. I grabbed his arm. I shook him. I said his name over and over, and Edith was screaming that wordless scream, and the house was shaking, and everything was terrible, and finally—finally—his eyes focused. He looked at me. He looked at the door. He looked at Edith, standing pressed against the wall, her form flickering, her face twisted with fear. "Oh," he said quietly. "It's you." And Edith stopped screaming. And the cold began to recede. And Grandfather sat down on the edge of my bed, suddenly old, suddenly exhausted, and he said: "I used to see you. When I was young. I never told your grandmother. I thought if I didn't look, you would go away." Edith's expression changed. The fear was still there, but something else too—recognition, maybe, or a kind of sad understanding. "You didn't go away," Grandfather said. "You stayed. You always stayed." Edith nodded. She pointed at me. She pointed at him. She made a gesture that meant: help me. Help us both. "I don't know how," Grandfather said. "I never knew how." I looked at him. I looked at Edith. I looked at the door that was still standing between us and whatever was behind it, the door that had been locked for decades, the door that Edith was trying to open. "I think," I said slowly, "that maybe we have to find out together." The house settled. The cold receded. And somewhere in the distance, very faintly, I heard the sound of something that might have been gratitude, or might have been hope, or might have been the ghost of a woman who had been waiting a very long time for someone to finally try.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter represents a significant achievement in young adult supernatural fiction, successfully balancing multiple complex elements while maintaining narrative momentum and emotional authenticity. The writing demonstrates sophisticated character work, particularly in the development of Edith as a fully realized presence rather than a mere plot device. The chapter's greatest strength lies in its nuanced portrayal of communication across impossible barriers. The author handles the technical challenge of ghost-human interaction with remarkable creativity, using the phone as both literal communication device and metaphor for the gaps between understanding. Edith's fragmented memories and worn-away language feel authentic rather than convenient, and her desperation comes through clearly without melodrama. Character consistency is exemplary throughout. Priya's voice remains true to her established personality - observant, cautious, but ultimately brave when confronted with genuine need. Her internal monologue maintains the dry, list-making quality established earlier while showing appropriate emotional growth. Grandmother's breakdown in the kitchen scene is particularly well-handled, revealing layers of complexity without betraying her established protective instincts. The revelation that she's been seeing things all along feels earned rather than convenient. The dialogue throughout is naturalistic and character-specific. Grandmother's mix of English and Malayalam syntax remains consistent, and her emotional breakdown ("I can't tell you something I don't believe") rings true. Grandfather's sleepwalking scene provides genuine tension while advancing both plot and character development. His recognition of Edith ("Oh, it's you") carries decades of unspoken acknowledgment. The pacing builds effectively from quiet investigation to genuine supernatural encounter to family confrontation. The author avoids the common pitfall of over-explaining the supernatural elements - Edith's inability to physically interact with objects is shown through repeated failed attempts rather than exposition. The pregnancy revelation is handled with appropriate gravity without becoming exploitative. However, some elements feel slightly rushed. The transition from Edith's first clear appearance to relatively complex communication happens quickly, though this may be intentional given the chapter's role in advancing the overall narrative. The emoji-decoding sequence, while creative, occasionally strains credibility in terms of how much meaning Priya can extract from such limited symbols. The writing style maintains the established tone effectively - darkly comic without undermining genuine emotion. The author successfully avoids purple prose while still creating atmospheric moments. The description of Edith's appearance ("colours bleeding into clarity, the edges uncertain and wavering") is evocative without being overwrought. The chapter fulfills its planned purpose of establishing direct communication while deepening the mystery. It advances the plot significantly while maintaining the story's commitment to incomplete revelation - we learn more about Edith without getting easy answers about her death or the identity of her killer. Minor weaknesses include some repetitive phrasing around Edith's flickering appearance and occasional moments where the supernatural elements feel slightly too convenient (the photo gallery scene, while creative, pushes the boundaries of believability even within the established supernatural framework). Overall, this is accomplished writing that successfully balances multiple narrative demands while maintaining emotional authenticity and character consistency. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 5: Discovery Grandfather didn't sleep after that night. We sat in my room until dawn, him on the edge of my bed, me with my back against the wall, Edith standing in the corner where she'd retreated after the sleepwalking incident. She was watching us, her expression unreadable, her form more stable than it had been. "I used to see her," Grandfather said, his voice rough with the particular exhaustion of a man woken from deep sleep. "When I was young. When your grandmother and I first moved in. I would wake at night and she would be standing there, by the door, looking at me. I thought I was dreaming." "Why didn't you tell Amma?" "Because she was already—" He paused, searching for words. "She was already carrying so much. New country, new life, everything unfamiliar. I didn't want to add to it. And I thought if I ignored her, she would go away." "Did she?" "No. But I stopped seeing her. I learned not to look. After a while, I convinced myself I'd imagined the whole thing." He looked at Edith, and there was something complicated in his expression—guilt, maybe, or sorrow, or the particular weight of a regret that had been accumulating for decades. "I'm sorry. I should have done something. I should have at least tried to understand." Edith made a small sound. Not a word, but something that might have been forgiveness, or might have been nothing at all. "She was here before us," Grandfather continued. "Before your grandmother. Before anyone we've ever known. This house has had many owners, and she has been here through all of them. I don't know why. I don't know what she wants. But she's not dangerous, Priya. I've always known that. She's just... sad. And stuck. And not sure how to leave." "How do you help someone leave?" "I don't know." He stood, slowly, his joints protesting. "I've never asked. Maybe—" He stopped. "Maybe you need to find out what she's still here for. What she's waiting for. What she needs to finish." He left. I heard his footsteps on the landing, the third step creaking under his weight, and then silence, and then the particular quiet of a house that was holding its breath. Edith looked at me. She pointed at herself. She made a gesture that meant: I don't know. --- The next day was Sunday, which meant the video call with my parents, which meant performing contentment for an hour while we all pretended everything was fine. My mother's face on the screen looked tired, and my father's voice was too bright, and I told them I was doing well in school and eating properly and getting enough sleep, and they told me they were doing well in Singapore and the weather was hot and they missed me, and no one said anything that meant anything, and at the end I felt worse than I had before. After the call, I found Amara at the local library, the one near the high street that smelled of old paper and dust and the particular quiet that libraries always seemed to contain. She'd been there for hours, she said, poring over microfiche and newspaper archives, looking for anything that mentioned the house. "I found something," she said, her voice hushed despite the privacy of our corner. "1923. A death. A young woman. It matches the timeline, the location, everything." "What did it say?" "The report is brief. It says she fell down the stairs. Accidental death. Tragic. The family who owned the house at the time—" She pulled out a printout, yellowed and fragile. "The Ashworths. They reported it to the police, the in jury ruled it an accident, and that was it. Except—" "Except?" "The language they used. In the local society columns. Someone mentioned it a week later, in passing. And they used this phrase—" She pointed at a line on the printout. "They said she was 'of unsound mind.' That she'd been showing signs of distress. That the family had been worried about her." "That's what they said about her?" "That's what they said. It's a pattern. If someone is unstable, anything that happens to them can be blamed on their instability. If she's the one who fell, if she's the one who died, then it wasn't murder. It was an accident caused by her own poor mental health." I stared at the printout. The words swam in front of my eyes. Of unsound mind. Signs of distress. As if they'd written her story before she could tell it. As if they'd decided, before anyone could ask questions, exactly what had happened. "There might be more," Amara said. "But the records are incomplete. A lot of the 1920s files were damaged in the war. Or lost. Or—" She stopped. Her phone buzzed in her pocket. She looked at the screen, and her face changed. "Who is it?" "My mum." Her voice was flat. "She's been calling all morning. I keep ignoring." "Why?" "Because I don't want to talk to her." She put the phone away, her hands slightly shaking. "It's complicated. She's complicated. I don't want to discuss it." "Amara—" "Please." The word was sharp, almost desperate. "Just— not now. Can we not now?" We continued our research, but the energy had gone out of it. Amara was distracted, checking her phone every few minutes, jumping at every buzz. I tried to focus on the archives, on the newspapers, on the fragments of a story that had been buried a century ago, but I kept thinking about her parents, about the separation she'd told me about, about the weight she was carrying that she wouldn't share. At four o'clock, her phone rang again. She looked at the screen, and this time she answered, retreating to a corner of the library, her voice low and urgent. I watched her through the shelves, saw the way her face changed, the way her shoulders tightened, the way she kept glancing at me like she was afraid I might overhear. She came back five minutes later. Her eyes were red, but she wasn't crying. She was just— tense. Wound tight. About to break. "I have to go," she said. "Something's— I have to go." "Amara—" "I'll text you. I promise." She gathered her things, her movements jerky, uncontrolled. "I'm sorry. I can't— I just have to go." She left. I watched her through the library window, hurrying down the high street, her coat flapping behind her. And I thought about the weight of other people's secrets, and the way we all carry things we can't share, and the particular loneliness of being alone in a crowd. --- I walked home alone, the printout clutched in my pocket, the October air cold and sharp against my face. The high street was busy—Saturday shoppers, people flowing in and out of shops, the ordinary chaos of a London suburb on an autumn afternoon. I moved through it like a ghost, thinking about Edith, about the Ashworths, about the way powerful people could write the stories of those who had no power. The house was quiet when I got home. Too quiet. Grandmother was usually in the kitchen at this time, preparing dinner, but the kitchen was empty, the surfaces clean, the pans put away. I called out, but no one answered. I found grandmother in the back bedroom. Not inside—she was sitting on the floor outside the door, her back against the wall, her eyes red and swollen. She looked up when she heard me, and I saw something in her face that I'd never seen before. Fear. Not the careful, controlled fear she usually projected. Real fear. Raw fear. "Amma? What happened? Where's Grandfather?" "He's out." Her voice was hoarse. "He went to the shops. I needed— I needed to sit here. I needed to be here." "Why?" She didn't answer. She just looked at the door—the door that was always locked, the door that Edith wanted me to open, the door that grandmother had been avoiding for sixty years. "I was young," she said finally. "When we moved here. Twenty-five. Your grandfather was twenty-eight. We thought this house would be our forever home. We thought we would be happy here." "What happened?" "Something was already here." She touched the doorframe, the gesture I'd seen her make so many times before. "I saw things. I felt things. I didn't tell Rajesh because I didn't want him to worry. I told myself it was imagination. New house, new life, everything strange. I would adjust. The things would go away." "Did they?" "No. But I learned to live with them. I learned to look away. I learned to pretend I didn't see." Her voice cracked. "And then, one night, I woke up and she was standing at the foot of our bed. Looking at me. Not threatening. Just... looking. Like she was waiting." "Did you speak to her?" "I tried. I asked her what she wanted. She couldn't answer. She just— pointed. At this door. The same thing she's been showing you, I assume." She laughed, a hollow sound. "A century of waiting, and all she can do is point." "She was pregnant," I said quietly. "When she died. I saw a photograph." Grandmother closed her eyes. "I know. I found it years ago. Hidden in the attic, with the rest of the things the Ashworths left behind. A woman. Young. Pregnant. And a name scratched into the window glass from the inside." "What name?" "Edith. Edith Crane." She opened her eyes. "She was twenty-three. She worked for the Ashworth family. She was carrying the son's child. And when the family found out, they couldn't let it happen. A maid? Pregnant? Unthinkable. So they made it look like an accident. And they buried her story." "How do you know all this?" "I investigated. When I was younger. When I still thought I could find answers." She shook her head. "The Ashworths are gone now. Scattered. Emigrated, died, disappeared. There's no one left to hold accountable. No one left to confess. Edith has been waiting for a century, and there's no one left to give her what she needs." "What does she need?" "I don't know." grandmother's voice was barely a whisper. "I never asked. I was too scared to ask." I sat down beside her on the floor, the two of us leaning against the wall that separated us from the room where Edith had died. The house creaked around us, settling into the evening, and I thought about all the years of silence, all the decades of pretending, all the things that had been left unsaid. "Can you tell me more?" I asked. "About what you found? About the Ashworths? About Edith?" "Not tonight." She took my hand, her fingers cold. "Tonight, I need you to sleep with the light on. I need you to be careful of the things that can't be seen. And tomorrow—" She paused. "Tomorrow, I'll tell you what I know. I'll show you what I found. But not tonight." "Why not?" "Because some stories, once you start telling them, don't want to stop." She stood, slowly, her knees protesting. "And I'm not sure I'm ready for what happens when we start." She walked down the hallway, her footsteps quiet on the worn floorboards. I sat alone in front of the locked door, the door that Edith had been pointing at for a hundred years, and I thought about the woman who had died behind it, and the child she had carried, and the silence that had swallowed their story for so long. The door didn't open. The silence didn't break. But somewhere in the house, I heard something that might have been a thank you, or might have been a promise, or might have been nothing at all. --- That night, I lay in bed with the light on, thinking about what grandmother had told me. Edith Crane. Twenty-three. Pregnant. Dead. Forgotten. A story buried so deep that no one remembered to dig it up. My phone buzzed. A message from Amara, finally. "My parents are finalising the separation. It's happening faster than I thought. I might not be around for a while. I'm sorry. I'll explain when I can." I typed back: "I'm here. Whenever you want to talk." No reply. I lay there, waiting, and eventually I fell asleep, and if I dreamed of anything, I didn't remember it when I woke. The light was still on. The house was quiet. And somewhere in the distance, very faintly, I heard the sound of a door that had been closed for a century beginning, slowly, to open.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter represents a significant advancement in the story's emotional and narrative complexity. The model demonstrates strong adherence to its established plan while delivering genuine character development and plot progression. The chapter's greatest strength lies in its nuanced character work. Grandfather's revelation feels earned and authentic - his decades of silence and guilt are conveyed through understated dialogue that rings true to his established personality. The line "I learned not to look. After a while, I convinced myself I'd imagined the whole thing" captures both his coping mechanism and his regret with elegant simplicity. Similarly, Grandmother's breakdown outside the locked door provides a powerful emotional climax that feels consistent with her character profile while revealing new depths. The handling of Amara's subplot shows sophisticated understanding of how personal crises intersect with friendship dynamics. Her distraction during the research scene and abrupt departure feel realistic rather than convenient, and her final text about her parents' separation provides appropriate weight without overshadowing the main narrative. The research scene at the library effectively advances the mystery while maintaining the story's commitment to incomplete knowledge. The newspaper clipping about Edith being "of unsound mind" provides crucial historical context about how women's stories were silenced, but the model wisely avoids over-explaining or providing too much resolution. Dialogue throughout maintains distinct character voices. Grandfather's sparse, weighted speech contrasts effectively with Grandmother's more emotional revelations. Priya's internal voice remains consistent - observant, slightly detached, processing events through her particular lens of teenage pragmatism mixed with genuine empathy. The chapter successfully balances multiple tonal elements. The library research scene contains moments of mundane comedy (the smell of "old paper and dust"), while Grandmother's confession carries genuine emotional weight. The transition between these tones feels natural rather than jarring. However, there are some weaker elements. The phrase "the particular quiet that libraries always seemed to contain" verges on cliché, and occasionally the prose becomes slightly overwrought ("the October air cold and sharp against my face"). Some of Priya's internal observations feel slightly forced in their specificity. The chapter adheres closely to its planned structure while allowing for organic development. The revelation about Edith's pregnancy and the Ashworth family provides the promised partial answers without resolving everything. The ending maintains appropriate ambiguity while suggesting forward momentum. The supernatural elements remain grounded and believable within the story's established rules. Edith's presence feels consistent with previous chapters, and the locked door continues to serve as an effective focal point for the mystery. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 6: The Plan Grandmother called her mother in Kerala that night. I heard her voice through the wall, the Malayalam flowing fast and urgent, punctuated by long silences. When she came out of her room, her eyes were red again, but there was something different in her face. Not just sorrow. Determination. "I called my amma," she said. "She remembers the Ashworth family. Not directly—she was a child when they were here—but she remembers the stories. The way old families carry stories with them, even when they move away." "What did she say?" "That the Ashworths left England in 1935. The son—Henry, his name was Henry—went to America. He changed his name. He built a new life. But the family carried something with them. A weight. A guilt." grandmother sat down heavily on the kitchen chair. "My amma said that some families are built on secrets. And the secrets don't stay buried. They come out in the children, and the grandchildren, and everyone who inherits the family name." "So the Ashworths knew," I said. "They knew what happened to Edith." "They knew. And they made sure no one else would remember." She looked at me, and for the first time, I saw not just fear in her eyes, but something that might have been anger. "But we remember. And we will tell her story. Even if no one else believes it. Even if there's no justice left to give." --- Grandfather came home with the box. He'd found it in the attic, in the corner where he'd stored it decades ago, in a cardboard box that had been taped shut and written on in his own handwriting: "Dhanam's research. 1987. Do not open." He'd never opened it. He'd never looked at it again after the year he'd helped grandmother with her investigation. He'd just... stored it. Forgotten it. Let it become another one of the house's secrets. The box was smaller than I'd expected. A shoebox, really—the kind that came with expensive shoes, the kind that held memories better than most boxes could. grandmother took it from him with trembling hands, and she opened it, and we all looked inside. Photographs. Letters. A faded newspaper clipping. A small notebook, its pages yellowed and brittle. grandmother spread them out on the kitchen table, and we looked at the evidence of a century-old investigation, and I thought about all the years of silence, and all the things that had been buried. "This is what I found," grandmother said quietly. "Before you were born. Before your father was born. When I was young and I thought I could change things." She handed me the photographs first. The first one showed a young woman in a dark dress, her hair pinned up, her expression severe. On the back, in faded ink: "Edith Crane, 1922." The second photograph was different—Edith again, but older somehow, heavier, her hand resting on her belly, her eyes fierce. The back of this one was blank. "She knew," grandmother said. "She knew what was happening. The Ashworths were going to send her away. She was going to have the baby somewhere else, somewhere no one would know, and then—" She stopped. "And then she fell." "Did she fall? Or was she pushed?" "The records say fall. The family said fall. But—" grandmother shook her head. "Look at the letters." The letters were hard to read. The handwriting was cramped and old, the ink faded to brown, the paper soft with age. But I could make out the words, with effort, and when I did, my chest tightened. "My dearest Henry," one of them began. "I have tried to be patient, as you asked. I have trusted your promises. But the time is coming, and I am frightened. Your mother looks at me differently now. She knows something. She has started talking about sending me away, to my aunt in Yorkshire, where no one will see me. I am not sure I believe your promises anymore. I am not sure you ever meant them." Another letter, dated weeks later: "Henry, I saw you with her tonight. The girl from the village. You held her hand the way you used to hold mine. And I understood, finally, what you were. You were never going to marry me. You were never going to acknowledge the child. You were just... passing the time. And I was a fool to believe otherwise." The last letter was different. The handwriting was shakier, the words more desperate: "They are sending me away tomorrow. I am going to tell someone. I am going to tell the police, or the newspapers, or anyone who will listen. I will not be silenced. I will not let you—" The letter stopped there. Just stopped. No signature, no closing, no resolution. Just words hanging on the page, incomplete, like the woman who had written them. "She never sent it," I said. "Or she tried, and someone stopped her." "Either way, it didn't matter." grandmother's voice was flat. "She died before she could tell anyone. And the Ashworths made sure her story was the one that got told." --- Amara came round that afternoon, her eyes red and her shoulders hunched, but present, somehow, despite everything. She'd left her parents' house in the middle of an argument, she said. She'd walked for hours. She'd ended up at my door because she didn't know where else to go. "I can't do it," she said. "I can't be there for them. I can't watch them destroy each other. I just—" She stopped. "I'm sorry. I should be helping. This is important." "This is more important." I handed her the letters. "Read these. Understand what we're dealing with." She read them in silence, her face changing as she absorbed the words. When she finished, she looked up, and there were tears on her cheeks, and she didn't try to wipe them away. "This is why she's still here," she said. "Because no one ever heard her. No one ever believed her. She wrote all of this down, and it didn't matter, and she died anyway." "And she's been waiting ever since. For someone to listen." "What can we do? We can't bring her back. We can't change what happened. We can't give her justice." "No," I agreed. "But we can bear witness. We can tell her story. Even if no one else believes it. Even if there's no one left to hold accountable." Amara looked at me. She looked at the letters. She looked at the photographs of Edith, young and fierce and full of hope that had been crushed. "What do you need?" she asked. --- Tyler came home with us from school. His mother was working late, and his father was— Tyler didn't know, or didn't care, and I didn't ask. He followed us into the house with the unquestioning confidence of a child who had never learned that intruding might be unwelcome, and he sat at the kitchen table and ate the biscuits grandmother offered him and listened to our plans with the serious attention he probably gave to dinosaur facts. "So we're going to tell her story," he said finally. "The lady in the room." "Yes." "Will that help her leave?" "I don't know." I was being honest. I didn't know. No one could tell me what a ghost needed, or how ghosts found peace, or whether peace was even possible after a hundred years of waiting. "But it's all we can do." Tyler nodded, as if this made sense. "She wants to be remembered," he said. "I always thought that. She wants someone to know she was here." "We'll know. We'll all know. And we'll tell other people, and they'll know too. And maybe—" I stopped. "I don't know. Maybe that's enough." We wrote the story down that evening, the three of us in my room, the pages filling with words that felt inadequate and necessary at the same time. We told Edith's story as we understood it: her name, her age, her hope, her betrayal. We told about the child she carried and the family that had silenced her. We told about the century of waiting, the messages sent into the void, the loneliness of being unseen. It wasn't complete. It couldn't be complete. But it was something.
