While Irongate and the political intrigue are sketched adequately, the fantasy elements feel perfunctory. The tiefling aspects of Vex's character are barely explored beyond physical description, and the broader world lacks texture and specificity. The writing style veers into purple prose territory frequently, with overwrought metaphors that don't always land. Phrases like "the walls were crumbling. Not crack, not fissure — crumble, all at once, like they'd been built on sand and the tide had finally come in" feel forced rather than organic. The author has a tendency toward melodramatic internal monologue that becomes repetitive. The romantic/erotic elements are handled with reasonable taste, focusing more on emotional intimacy than explicit content, which suits the story's focus on character development. However, the transformation from captor-prisoner to lovers feels somewhat rushed despite the multi-chapter structure. The plot's political intrigue elements are interesting but underdeveloped. The revelation about Vex's true crime and the competing factions feels like it could have been explored more thoroughly rather than serving primarily as a plot device for the ending. The ending, while emotionally satisfying in its way, feels somewhat unearned. The dramatic confrontation at Irongate resolves too conveniently, and Caden's complete transformation from careful professional to romantic rebel happens quite suddenly despite the gradual buildup. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 14 Nuanced Characters: 16 Pacing: 13 World Building: 10 Compelling Plot: 12 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Coherent: 14 Weak Dialogue: 12 Tell-Don't-Show: 11 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10 Amateurish: 11 Purple Prose: 13 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 14 Unearned Transformations: 12 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 13 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17
Avg Final Item Score: 55.5/100
+ Cozy-Horror Post Apocalyptic Survival — Mushroom Season (Chapter Avg: 77.2 | Final: 71.8)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Cozy-Horror Post Apocalypse Survival Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: When you're out of food, you get desperate. Who would have thought the spore mutants -- the things trying to kill us -- would be delicious?
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Cozy-Horror Post Apocalypse Survival Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: When you&#x27;re out of food, you get desperate. Who would have thought the spore mutants -- the things trying to kill us -- would be delicious? -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Cozy-Horror Post Apocalypse Survival: Writing Plan --- # Brainstorming ## Character Concepts The protagonist possibilities span a wide spectrum of survivor archetypes. A chef or foodie would provide an interesting ironic lens—someone who lived for cuisine now reduced to apocalypse survival, whose expertise becomes both a blessing and a moral challenge. A scientist or mycologist offers a more analytical approach, someone who might understand the biology behind why these creatures are edible and what the implications could be. A former restaurant owner carries the weight of a lost world, someone who fed people for a living now struggling to survive. Secondary characters could include a skeptical survivalist partner who refuses to eat the mutants initially, creating tension around the discovery. A child character could make the "delicious monsters" concept more poignant—kids being kids, excited about the strange new food while adults grapple with the horror. An elderly character with terminal illness who decides to embrace this small pleasure in their remaining time adds emotional depth. The mutants themselves deserve consideration. Are they humanoid? Fungal growths with human features? Abstract shapes? The more relatable they are, the harder the "they're delicious" revelation hits. Perhaps they still have some vestige of humanity—a残留 of speech, recognizable gestures—which would make consuming them morally complex. ## Tone and Atmosphere Cozy-horror is a delicate balance. The horror elements include the post-apocalyptic setting, the deadly nature of the mutants, and the survival desperation. The cozy elements could come through found family dynamics, small moments of comfort (warm meals, soft beds in unsafe places), dark humor, and the protagonist's genuine enthusiasm for food. The tone might lean into dark comedy—the absurdity of apocalypse survivors developing a gourmet culture around the creatures hunting them. Think of the humor in characters arguing about the best way to prepare a mutant, debating seasoning combinations, or holding a dinner party in a fortified building while monsters roam outside. Alternatively, the cozy elements could come through nostalgia—characters recreating lost recipes, using mutant "meat" to approximate dishes from the old world, the comfort of ritual in cooking and eating together despite everything. ## Plot Directions One direction follows the discovery arc: protagonist discovers mutants are edible, experiments with preparation, eventually establishes a community around this food source, but faces conflict when others discover what they're eating or when the mutants adapt. Another angle explores the moral dimensions: eating the mutants might change the survivors somehow—psychically, biologically, or spiritually. Are the mutants truly mindless monsters, or is there something consumable about them that raises questions? A third path could focus on building something: survivors establishing a settlement where they farm or hunt mutants, developing a cuisine, perhaps even trading with other survivor groups. The horror comes from the outside threat and the question of whether they're becoming something else through their diet. ## Story Beats and Pacing The story naturally divides into phases: the desperate search for food, the discovery, experimentation, building something new, and then conflict or revelation. The middle chapters should balance the cozy elements (establishing routines, finding joy) with horror reminders (danger, loss, the nature of what they're eating). The ending could go several directions. Hopeful but uncertain: they've found a way to survive but the world is still broken. Bittersweet: they've built something wonderful but at a cost. Darker turn: the deliciousness comes with a price. Subversive: they realize the mutants are more than they thought. --- # Reflection The chef protagonist immediately resonates as the strongest choice because food and cooking are inherently cozy activities—they represent normalcy, care, community. A mycologist is interesting but might make the story too focused on science rather than emotion. The restaurant owner carries good symbolic weight: someone who fed others now fighting to survive. The tone balance requires careful navigation. Too much horror undercuts the cozy; too much comfort makes the stakes feel fake. The key might be keeping the horror external and the internal space warm. The characters can be safe in their moments of domesticity precisely because danger is real and ever-present. Dark humor serves this balance well—it acknowledges the horror while finding absurdity in survival. The plot direction focusing on building something feels most aligned with cozy-horror. The discovery-and-consequence angle could work but risks losing the cozy elements if it becomes too grim. The moral complexity of eating humanoid creatures needs handling—it should be acknowledged but not allowed to overwhelm the story. Perhaps the mutants are fungal enough that they're not clearly human, or perhaps the story approaches the grossness and weirdness with humor. Eight chapters at approximately 1000 words each gives 8000 words total—a substantial short story. This allows for character development, world-building, and a satisfying arc. The pacing should spend roughly two chapters on pre-discovery desperation, one chapter on discovery and first taste, three chapters on building their new food source and community, and two chapters on conflict and resolution. The ending should be hopeful but earned. Cozy-horror works best when it earns its warmth through acknowledging darkness. The survivors have found something precious—food, community, meaning—in a broken world, and that makes both the loss and the finding matter. --- # Chapter-by-Chapter Plan ## Chapter 1: "The Last of Everything" The chapter opens with MAREN, former chef and co-owner of a farm-to-table restaurant, counting the supplies in their survivor group's hidden basement. The math is grim: three days of rations left for a group of seven. We establish the post-apocalyptic world through her eyes—the fungal infection that turned most of humanity into the CHANGED, the saferooms and scavenger runs, the constant low-level fear. We introduce key group members: DELIA, a former ICU nurse and the group's practical leader; WES, a skeptical survivalist who monitors the perimeter; CARLOS and YUKI, a couple who met during the early chaos and stick together; and GRANDMOTHER AHN, an elderly Korean woman who quietly observes everything and makes the best tea anyone's ever tasted. The chapter builds tension as Maren watches the others eat their decreasing portions. She thinks about her restaurant, the menu she designed, the joy of feeding people. Now she can't even feed herself. The chapter ends with a scavenging mission going wrong—they spot CHANGED in the warehouse they're searching, forced to retreat empty-handed. ## Chapter 2: "Desperate Measures" The group debates their options. They can't stay in the basement forever; scavengers from another group might find them, or the CHANGED might breach their defenses. Wes argues they need to expand their search radius, which means more risk. Delia counters that they're not equipped for that kind of expedition. Maren wanders the basement's small garden—her project, grown under artificial light from salvaged LEDs. She talks to the plants, a habit that's become a coping mechanism. She notices something strange: a CHANGED that wandered too close to their vents last night left behind a... trail. Not blood. Spores. And something is growing in the soil where the spores fell. Something that looks almost like mushrooms. She shows Delia, who is appropriately concerned about fungal contamination. But Maren is distracted by the smell—it's incredible, earthy and sweet. She tastes the growth. Delia is horrified. Maren, expecting to die or transform, instead tastes something that reminds her of shiitake, richer, almost meaty. ## Chapter 3: "The First Harvest" Maren can't stop thinking about the fungal growth. She sneaks out to harvest more, finding where the CHANGED patrol and leave their spores. She's terrified but also exhilarated—this could save them. She brings back a harvest and begins cooking. The others are grossed out. Wes refuses outright. Carlos is curious but cautious. Grandmother Ahn, however, is interested. She asks Maren what it smells like, what it reminds her of. Maren describes it, and Ahn nods—she remembers her grandmother cooking something similar in Korea, a wild fungus that grew where the earth was rich. They cook it simply, with preserved salt and some herbs. The smell draws everyone. Even Wes reluctantly tries a bite. The silence that follows is Maren's verdict: they're eating something extraordinary. ## Chapter 4: "New Recipes" A routine develops. Maren becomes the hunter-gatherer, finding CHANGED patrol paths and harvesting the fungal growths they leave behind. The group starts calling the growths "shrooms" with dark humor, though Maren insists on proper names—she's been experimenting, classifying. The chapter explores the cooking process in detail—Maren's muscle memory returning, the meditative quality of prep work, the small celebrations when a dish turns out well. They have their first good meal in months: shroom risotto, the rice from their emergency stores, the shroom providing the richness of cream and the depth of meat. Grandmother Ahn helps Maren adapt old recipes, bringing Korean techniques to the new ingredients. They talk about food and memory—Ahn about her grandmother, Maren about her restaurant. The cozy domestic scenes contrast with the ever-present danger outside. ## Chapter 5: "Feeding the Soul" The group has been surviving on shrooms for two weeks now. Their health has improved—they have more energy, better color. But something else is happening. They're... happier. The meals have become anchors in their day, something to look forward to, something that reminds them of normalcy. Maren starts planning menus, the chef in her resurfacing. She wants to throw a dinner. The others think she's lost her mind, but they help anyway. They find candles, clean up the best area of the basement, make it special. The dinner scene is the emotional heart of the chapter. Seven people sitting around a table, sharing food, telling stories. For one night, they're not survivors in an apocalypse—they're a family having dinner. The horror of their situation fades into background noise. Wes makes a toast: to Maren, to the shrooms, to stubbornness. After dinner, Delia pulls Maren aside. She's been tracking the CHANGED patterns. They're changing too—organizing more, moving in patterns that suggest purpose. Delia isn't sure if it's connected to the harvesting, but they're going to need to be more careful. ## Chapter 6: "The Harvesters" Wes spots a scavenging party watching their building. They're from one of the larger survivor groups in the city, and they know about the basement. The chapter explores the politics of survival—groups compete for resources, and word has gotten out about Maren's group doing better than expected. The strangers want to know their secret. Wes wants to turn them away. Delia negotiates, giving them some supplies in exchange for information about other safe zones. But one of the scavengers, a young woman named PATRICIA, is curious about where the food comes from. She lingers, watches Maren cook through a crack in the door. That night, Patricia sneaks in. She finds Maren's shroom stash and nearly freaks out—these grow near the CHANGED, everyone knows that, everyone knows they're dangerous. But Maren explains, demonstrates, lets her taste. Patricia's reaction is profound: she's been eating scraps and garbage for months. This is the first time she's had something that tasted like life. Patricia wants to tell her people. Maren is hesitant—they're not ready to share, not ready for the attention. But Patricia points out that they're barely surviving anyway, and more people means more eyes, more hands, more protection. The chapter ends with Maren agreeing to a meeting. ## Chapter 7: "The Feast" The groups meet. Twenty people from Patricia's settlement, wary and curious, gather in the basement. Maren and her group have prepared a spread: multiple shroom dishes, techniques refined over weeks, presented with the care of a real restaurant service. The reaction is overwhelming. People cry. People laugh. The food connects them to a world they thought was gone. And through the meal, barriers break down—former enemies become allies, strangers become friends. But the celebration is interrupted. A CHANGED breach—the largest they've seen, drawn by the smell of cooking, the warmth of so many people. The battle is frantic and terrifying. In the chaos, Grandmother Ahn is injured protecting Carlos and Yuki's new baby (a pregnancy that's been hidden until now). The chapter ends with the CHANGED driven back, but Ahn wounded, and everyone realizing that their success has made them a target. The old world might be gone, but the new world has its own rules. ## Chapter 8: "Tomorrow" A week later. The groups have merged—Maren's basement is crowded but strong. Ahn is recovering; the baby is healthy. They've fortified better, established protocols, designated Maren as head of "provisions" (she refuses the title of chef, says they're all just trying to survive). But Maren has a new obsession: understanding the shrooms. She's been studying them, mapping where they grow, noticing patterns in the CHANGED behavior. The growths aren't random—they're cultivated, somehow. The CHANGED are leaving them, deliberately, like farmers. The implications are terrifying. Either the CHANGED are more intelligent than anyone realized, or something else is directing them. Maren doesn't tell the others yet—she doesn't want to take away what they've found. But the chapter ends with her staring at the fungal growth, wondering what they've really been eating, and what it wants from them in return. The final scene is quiet. Maren cooks breakfast for the growing community. The kitchen is chaotic, crowded, alive. She tastes the dish, adjusts the seasoning, calls everyone to eat. Whatever the future holds, they have this moment. They have food, and community, and tomorrow. --- # Themes and Motifs The central theme explores how humans find meaning and connection through food, even in the darkest circumstances. The cozy elements come from the domestic rituals of cooking and eating, the warmth of shared meals, the small joys amid survival. The horror elements ground the story in genuine stakes—the deadly world, the uncertain nature of what they're eating, the implication that their salvation might have a price. Food as love and care runs throughout. Maren's character arc is about reclaiming her purpose—not just surviving, but feeding people, nurturing them, giving them moments of joy. Grandmother Ahn's subplot connects the theme to generational memory, the ways food carries culture and history. The CHANGED-as-cultivation raises questions about agency and intention. Are the survivors exploiting the monsters, or being managed by them? This ambiguity adds the horror layer without needing a definitive answer—the comfort of the ending is qualified by uncertainty. --- # Voice and Style Notes The narrative voice should be intimate third-person, close to Maren's perspective. Tone balances dark humor with genuine warmth—recognizing absurdity without losing emotional stakes. Descriptions of food should be sensory and specific, grounding the cozy elements in reality. Action sequences are shorter, punchy, focused on emotion rather than mechanics. The prose should lean toward the lyrical when describing cooking and community, and toward the stark when describing danger and loss. This contrast reinforces the story's central tension between the cozy interior and horror exterior.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention This short story aims to deliver a cozy-horror narrative that earns its warmth through genuine acknowledgment of darkness, using food and cooking as the bridge between survival and meaning-making. The intention is to create something that feels like a quiet moment of comfort in an impossible world—not a reversal of the horror, but a holding space for joy within it. **Protagonist Choice**: The story centers on Maren, a former chef, because her profession provides natural justification for deep attention to food, cooking techniques, and the emotional weight of feeding others. Her expertise becomes both a source of hope and a moral challenge, giving the narrative a central character who actively transforms their circumstances rather than simply reacting to them. The choice of a chef also allows for sensory-rich descriptions of food that ground the cozy elements in tangible detail. **Tone Balance**: The story walks a careful line between horror and comfort. The horror is external—deadly mutants, scarce resources, uncertain future—while the interior spaces remain warm through human connection, ritual, and small joys. Dark humor serves as the bridge, allowing characters (and readers) to acknowledge the absurdity and terror of their situation without being crushed by it. The goal is never to minimize the horror but to demonstrate that even in apocalypse, humans find reasons to gather, cook, and eat together. **Moral Complexity Handling**: The mutants are fungal enough—described through spore-trails, growth patterns, and otherworldly qualities—that consuming them doesn't become overwhelming cannibalism-horror. The story acknowledges the weirdness and slight wrongness of eating the creatures hunting them, but handles this through character reactions (Wes's initial refusal, Patricia's hesitation) and dark humor rather than existential crisis. The real horror comes from the implication that the mutants might be cultivating the growths deliberately—a suggestion rather than a revelation. **Structural Approach**: The story follows a discovery-to-building arc across eight chapters, with pacing that allows for character development and emotional resonance. Roughly two chapters establish pre-discovery desperation, one chapter covers discovery and first taste, three chapters explore building community around the new food source, and two chapters address conflict and resolution. This structure ensures the cozy elements have time to breathe before complications arise. **Thematic Focus**: The piece explores how food creates community and meaning, even—perhaps especially—in impossible circumstances. Cooking becomes an act of rebellion against despair, and shared meals anchor characters to their humanity. The subplot with Grandmother Ahn connects this theme to generational memory, suggesting that food carries culture and history across generations, even into broken worlds. **Ending Philosophy**: The conclusion is hopeful but earned, qualified by uncertainty. The survivors have found something precious—a food source, a community, a purpose—but the world remains broken and new threats have emerged. The implication of cultivated growths suggests their salvation might have a price, but the story doesn't explore this fully. Instead, it ends on a moment of quiet domesticity: Maren cooking breakfast, calling people to eat, choosing today despite tomorrow's unknowns. --- # Chapter Planning **Chapter 1: "The Last of Everything" (approximately 1000 words)** - Opens with Maren counting supplies, establishing the three-day timeline and group of seven - Introduces key characters through their roles: Delia (leader), Wes (skeptical sentry), Carlos and Yuki (couple), Grandmother Ahn (quiet observer) - Establishes post-apocalyptic world through Maren's perspective—the Changed, the saferooms, the scavenger runs - Establishes Maren's backstory: chef and co-owner of a farm-to-table restaurant, someone whose identity was built around feeding people - The chapter builds quiet dread as supplies dwindle and options narrow - Ends with a scavenger mission going wrong—Changed forces retreat, no supplies gained **Chapter 2: "Desperate Measures" (approximately 1000 words)** - Group debates options with rising tension—can't stay, can't expand safely - Maren wanders the basement garden, notices fungal growth where Changed spore-trails fell - She tastes the growth, expects death or transformation, instead tastes something extraordinary - Delia's horrified reaction, Maren's excitement, the first seed of possibility - Establishes that the growths only appear where Changed congregate—danger and salvation intertwined **Chapter 3: "The First Harvest" (approximately 1000 words)** - Maren sneaks out to find more growths, tracking Changed patrol patterns - Risk and exhilaration—hunting for food instead of fighting for survival - The others' reactions: disgust from Wes, curiosity from Carlos, cautious interest from Ahn - Grandmother Ahn's connection to similar fungi from her grandmother's Korea - Simple cooking with salt and herbs, the first shared meal of Changed-derived food - The silence after the first bite—Maren's verdict delivered without words **Chapter 4: "New Recipes" (approximately 1000 words)** - Routine establishes: Maren as hunter-gatherer, refining techniques, naming the growths - Focus on cooking process—Maren's muscle memory returning, meditative prep work - The shroom risotto: rice from stores, shroom providing cream and meat richness - Collaboration with Ahn: Korean techniques adapted to new ingredients - Food as memory—Ahn's grandmother, Maren's restaurant, the dishes they used to make - Small celebrations, quiet joy, domestic normalcy emerging from chaos **Chapter 5: "Feeding the Soul" (approximately 1000 words)** - Two weeks of survival on shrooms—physical health improving, spirits lifting - Meals become anchors, rituals, something to anticipate - Maren's chef identity resurfaces—she wants to plan a menu, throw a dinner - The others think she's lost her mind, but they help anyway - Dinner party scene: candles, cleaned space, the care of presentation - Emotional heart: seven people around a table, stories shared, a family eating together - Delia's concern: Changed patterns are changing too, organizing with purpose **Chapter 6: "The Harvesters" (approximately 1000 words)** - External threat: scavenging party from a larger survivor group has found them - Political tension—groups compete for resources, this group is doing suspiciously well - Wes wants to turn them away; Delia negotiates with supplies for information - Patricia, a young scavenger, lingers, curious about the source of their food - Nighttime infiltration: Patricia discovers the shroom stash, nearly flees - Maren's explanation, demonstration, first taste—Patricia overwhelmed by real food - Negotiation: Patricia wants to tell her people; Maren hesitates about sharing - Chapter ends with agreement to a meeting, communities on the verge of merging **Chapter 7: "The Feast" (approximately 1000 words)** - Twenty people from Patricia's settlement gather for the demonstration meal - Maren and group prepare a spread: multiple dishes, refined techniques, restaurant-quality presentation - Emotional reactions: tears, laughter, connection to a world thought lost - Barriers break down—enemies become allies, strangers become community - Celebration interrupted: largest Changed breach yet, drawn by warmth and cooking smells - Chaotic battle, Ahn wounded protecting Carlos and Yuki's newborn (revealed in chaos) - Changed driven back but cost paid—Ahn injured, everyone recognizing their success has made them a target **Chapter 8: "Tomorrow" (approximately 1000 words)** - One week later: groups have merged, the basement is crowded but stronger - Ahn recovering, baby healthy, new fortifications established - Maren appointed head of "provisions" (refuses chef title, says they're all just surviving) - Maren's obsession: studying the growths, mapping where they appear, noticing patterns - Realization dawns: the growths aren't random, they're cultivated, Changed leave them like farmers - Implication: Changed are more intelligent than anyone realized, or something else directs them - Maren doesn't tell the others—doesn't want to take away what they've found - Final scene: Maren cooking breakfast for the growing community, tasting, adjusting, calling people to eat - Quiet domestic moment against uncertain future—warmth earned through acknowledged darkness - Ends on choice: today matters, despite tomorrow's unknowns --- # Quick Reference: Emotional Arc | Chapter | Primary Emotion | Key Development | |---------|-----------------|-----------------| | 1 | Dread | Setting stakes, introducing characters | | 2 | Desperation | Discovery seeds planted | | 3 | Tentative hope | First successful harvest and taste | | 4 | Comfort | Routine emerges, skills develop | | 5 | Joy | Community celebration, emotional peak | | 6 | Tension | Outside contact, new complications | | 7 | Fear | Attack, loss, consequences of success | | 8 | Quiet determination | Resolution with ominous undertones |
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# Human Approach vs. AI Approach: A Critical Analysis ## How a Human Writer Might Approach This Prompt A human writer approaching "Cozy-Horror Post Apocalypse Survival" with the central conceit that the monsters trying to kill you are delicious would likely bring several distinct qualities to the material. First, a human writer would likely have an emotional relationship with food itself—personal memories, family recipes, cultural context, maybe even specific dishes that carry meaning. This personal investment would bleed into the prose in ways that feel authentic. The chef protagonist isn't just a convenient character choice; a human writer might have cooked professionally, or grown up in a household where cooking was love made visible, or have specific dishes that remind them of people and places. The sensory details wouldn't come from a database of descriptive language but from lived experience of chopping vegetables at 3 AM, of the smell of something browning in a pan, of the particular satisfaction of a dish that worked. A human writer would also approach the horror-comedy balance with genuine uncertainty about how to feel. An AI can generate "darkly humorous" prose by assembling patterns that read as dark humor, but a human writer wrestling with "the monsters are delicious" would actually feel the strange absurdity of that premise. That feeling—whatever it is, whether it's uncomfortable laughter or dark fascination—would shape the prose in real-time. The jokes wouldn't land the same way; they'd feel discovered rather than constructed. The moral complexity of eating the Changed would matter to a human writer in a different way. An AI can acknowledge that eating humanoid creatures is ethically complex and move on. A human writer might actually sit with that discomfort, might change their mind about how the characters should feel halfway through, might write scenes that explore the revulsion and the necessity and the weird pleasure in ways that feel lived-in rather than noted. The ambiguity about whether the Changed are cultivating the growths deliberately might emerge from the writer's own uncertainty about what they want the answer to be, rather than being a planted plot point. A human writer would also bring inconsistency and idiosyncrasy. Some chapters might be stronger than others. The voice might shift slightly depending on when they wrote it, what they had for breakfast, how they were feeling about the project that day. This inconsistency is actually a feature—it creates texture, makes the prose feel like it came from a mind rather than a system. A human writer might also make choices that don't optimize for anything in particular, that seem to serve no purpose except that the writer wanted to write them. Finally, a human writer might abandon the plan entirely. If, halfway through Chapter 4, they discover something unexpected about Maren or the Changed or the shrooms, they'd follow it even if it broke the outline. An AI following a detailed chapter plan is less likely to have those generative accidents. --- ## Telltale LLM Approaches to Writing Understanding how LLMs typically approach writing helps identify where this plan might be falling into patterns that produce competent but inhuman prose. ### The Safety Problem LLMs tend toward safe choices because they're trained to be helpful and inoffensive. This manifests as avoiding genuine controversy, keeping stakes ambiguous enough that no one could object, and softening edges that might read as too dark or too opinionated. In this piece, safety might show up as not fully committing to the horror of the situation—the Changed might not feel genuinely threatening because the prose is too careful, too aware that readers need to like the characters. The cozy elements might be deployed defensively, as if the AI is worried about upsetting the reader with too much darkness. Safe writing also tends toward the middle of emotional registers—neither too funny nor too sad, neither too hopeful nor too despairing. This produces prose that reads as fine but forgettable, prose that doesn't take risks and therefore doesn't resonate. ### The Wrapping-Up Problem LLMs like to resolve things. Even when given prompts that resist resolution, there's a tendency to provide closure, to explain what things meant, to tie up loose ends with at least a bow if not a ribbon. This is partly training data bias—most stories in the training set have endings—and partly the model's helpfulness impulse. But real life doesn't wrap up, and real stories often resist the tidy ending. In this piece, the plan already shows some of this tendency. The implication that the Changed might be cultivating the growths is introduced but not explored—that's good, that's appropriately ambiguous. But the dinner party in Chapter 5, the birth reveal in Chapter 7, the community coming together by Chapter 8—these all follow a trajectory toward resolution. A human writer might let things stay messier. The baby might not be revealed dramatically in a crisis; it might just be there, already part of the group, and the reader learns about it when they learn about it. The merger with Patricia's group might not go smoothly; it might be awkward and difficult and incomplete. ### The Impressiveness Problem LLMs can sometimes write prose that's designed to look impressive—complex vocabulary, varied sentence structures, sophisticated imagery—rather than prose that's designed to communicate and move a reader. This shows up as thesaurus abuse, sentences that call attention to themselves, metaphors that are more clever than clear. In genre fiction, this often manifests as overdescribed action sequences, excessively purple horror descriptions, or worldbuilding that prioritizes originality over clarity. For cozy-horror, this might mean descriptions of the Changed that are too detailed, too focused on being gross or creative rather than on creating the right emotional effect. It might mean the cooking scenes are too elaborate, the sensory details piling up until they become noise rather than atmosphere. ### The Consistency Problem LLMs are designed to be consistent in ways that feel inhuman. The voice in an LLM-generated piece tends to be uniform throughout—the same vocabulary, the same rhythm, the same emotional register. Human writers, even skilled ones, have more variation. A chapter written in the morning might be more energetic than one written at night. A scene that the writer found particularly interesting might have more life to it than a scene they wrote out of obligation. This consistency isn't necessarily bad on the surface—it produces clean, readable prose. But it lacks the texture of human inconsistency, the sense that a real person was sitting in the room making choices. ### The Pacing Problem LLMs often struggle with pacing because they're generating text without the feedback loops that human writers have. A human writer senses when a scene is dragging, when the reader needs a beat of relief, when the tension has plateaued and needs a new injection. An LLM following a plan might move mechanically through beats without feeling whether those beats are landing. The eight-chapter structure in this plan is a good example. The plan calls for "roughly two chapters on pre-discovery desperation, one chapter on discovery, three chapters on building community, and two chapters on conflict and resolution." That's a structurally sound outline, but it could produce prose that feels like it's checking boxes rather than telling a story. A human writer might discover that they only need one chapter of pre-discovery desperation because the second chapter would be redundant, or that they need four chapters on building community because those scenes are where the life of the story is. ### The Explanation Problem LLMs sometimes over-explain. Because they're designed to be helpful, they can err toward clarifying things that the reader would rather discover on their own. "Maren felt a mixture of hope and fear" is more common than showing Maren's hope and fear through action and leaving the reader to name the emotion. "This meal was different from the others" appears more often than letting the reader feel the difference. In this piece, over-explanation might show up in the themes being stated rather than embodied. The plan mentions "food as love and care," "generational memory," "cozy elements earned through acknowledging darkness"—these are good thematic ideas, but if the prose has to keep reminding the reader of them, they become thesis statements rather than lived experience. --- ## Deep Critique of the Existing Plan Now I'll apply these critiques specifically to the plan developed above, identifying places where it might be falling into typical LLM patterns and brainstorming alternatives. ### Critique of Chapter Structure The chapter breakdown follows a very logical, almost mechanical pattern: establish stakes, introduce discovery, build community, introduce conflict, resolve. This is a sound story structure, but it's also the kind of structure that an AI might generate from a story structure template. It doesn't have the feel of a story that emerged from a writer's obsession with a particular idea or character. Consider what might be missing. The plan doesn't include any chapter breaks or scene shifts that feel arbitrary or generative. Every chapter seems to contain exactly what the story needs and nothing more. A human writer might include a chapter that's mostly Maren remembering her restaurant, not because it advances the plot but because the writer was thinking about that world and wanted to write about it. A human writer might include a scene where nothing happens—Wes checks the perimeter, sits alone for a while, thinks about people he lost—because those quiet moments are what make a story feel lived-in. The chapter titles are another signal: "The Last of Everything," "Desperate Measures," "The First Harvest," "New Recipes," "Feeding the Soul," "The Harvesters," "The Feast," "Tomorrow." These are all perfectly good titles, evocative and appropriate. But they're also very consistent in their style—each is a two-word or three-word phrase with a capitalized word for each significant term. A human writer might have one title that's a full sentence ("Call Everyone to Eat"), one that's a single word ("Shrooms"), one that's a reference to something specific in the chapter without being obvious about it. The consistency here, while professional, lacks the personality that inconsistency can provide. ### Critique of Character Introductions The plan introduces characters through their functions: Delia as "practical leader," Wes as "skeptical survivalist," Carlos and Yuki as "couple who met during the early chaos," Grandmother Ahn as "elderly Korean woman who quietly observes." These are functional descriptions that tell us what roles the characters will play, but they don't tell us who these people are beyond their narrative functions. A human writer might introduce Grandmother Ahn not by describing her demographically but by describing a specific habit—maybe she always has a cup of tea that's gone cold, and she keeps forgetting to drink it, and there's something about the way she holds the cup that suggests she's holding onto something. A human writer might introduce Wes not as "skeptical" but through a specific moment of skepticism—Maren shows him the mushroom and he just looks at her, doesn't say anything, and the silence communicates everything. The plan also introduces all five supporting characters in the first chapter. That's efficient, but it might not be organic. A human writer might forget to introduce someone and then have to circle back, or might keep someone offscreen for longer because the story didn't need them yet, or might focus so much on Maren that the supporting characters remain vague until they become important. ### Critique of the Discovery Arc The plan handles the discovery that the Changed growths are edible as a fairly linear process: Maren notices the growth, tastes it, introduces it to the group, convinces them to try it. This is logical, but it might also be too neat. What if the discovery was more traumatic? What if Maren ate the growth not in a moment of scientific curiosity but in a moment of despair, so hungry that she would have eaten anything? What if someone else discovered it first, and Maren had to deal with the moral complexity of someone else introducing this to the group? What if the first taste made her sick, and she had to experiment to find the right preparation, and there were failures along the way? The plan mentions that Maren "can't stop thinking about the fungal growth" and "sneaks out" to harvest more, which adds some texture, but the overall arc remains straightforward. Human discoveries are rarely straightforward—they involve false starts, second thoughts, moments of backing away from what you're about to do. ### Critique of the "Feast" Chapter Chapter 7 is positioned as the emotional climax: a feast, a Changed attack, a birth revelation, Ahn's injury. This is a lot to pack into one chapter, and while it creates dramatic intensity, it also feels engineered. The birth is "revealed in chaos," which suggests it's been foreshadowed without being directly mentioned, but the plan doesn't specify what that foreshadowing might have been. A human writer might approach this differently. They might reveal the pregnancy earlier, let it be part of the community's daily reality, so that when the attack comes the stakes include protecting a pregnant person and then a newborn, not just a surprise revelation. Or they might not have a pregnancy subplot at all, finding other ways to raise the stakes. The attack itself follows a pattern that's common in action scenes: chaos, a character getting hurt, the attackers being driven back. This is serviceable but not particularly original. A human writer might have the attack go differently—maybe they don't drive the Changed back, maybe they have to flee, maybe the basement is compromised and they have to find a new home while carrying an injured person and a newborn. The plan's version resolves the immediate crisis; a human writer might let the consequences sprawl. ### Critique of the Ending The plan ends with Maren cooking breakfast, the community gathered, "warmth earned through acknowledged darkness." This is a strong image and a fitting end for cozy-horror, but it also feels like a bow on top of the package. The implication that the Changed might be cultivating the growths is introduced in the penultimate paragraph but not explored, which is good—it leaves ambiguity without leaving things unresolved. But there's a difference between leaving things unresolved and leaving things open. The current ending suggests that tomorrow is uncertain but the community has each other and their rituals. That's comforting, but it might also be too comfortable. A human writer might end with Maren tasting the food and not being sure if it tastes different now, if there's something else in it, if the Changed are closer than they usually are because of the cooking smells. The ending might hold onto the horror rather than resolving it with warmth. ### Critique of Theme Deployment The plan articulates several themes clearly: food as love and care, generational memory, cozy elements earned through acknowledging darkness. These are good themes, but the plan presents them as things to be included rather than things to be discovered. The prose shouldn't announce these themes; it should embody them in specific moments. Grandmother Ahn's subplot is a good example. The plan says it "connects the theme to generational memory," which is correct, but it doesn't specify what that generational memory actually is. What did Ahn's grandmother cook? What does Ahn remember about it? Is there a specific dish, a specific technique, a specific story that gets passed from Ahn to someone else? The more specific this subplot is, the more it will feel like lived experience and less like theme deployment. ### Critique of the "Cozy-Horror" Balance The plan describes the tone as balancing "dark humor with genuine warmth," with "horror external and interior spaces warm." This is a good description of the cozy-horror aesthetic, but the plan doesn't specify where the balance tips at different moments. Is Chapter 1 mostly horror with a hint of cozy? Is Chapter 5 mostly cozy with a reminder of horror? The plan implies this through the chapter descriptions, but it doesn't articulate it explicitly. A human writer might be more intuitive about this balance, sensing when a scene needs more warmth or more dread. An AI following a plan might hit the marks without feeling the oscillations that create rhythm. --- ## Brainstorming Ideas to Make the Piece More Human ### Radical Specificity Rather than describing things generically, push for maximum specificity. The Changed aren't just "fungal infection victims"—what do they actually look like? Not "fungal growths" but "the pale white threads that push through the concrete where the spores settle, reaching toward the light like pale fingers." The shrooms aren't "earthy and sweet"—what specific earth, what specific sweetness? Maren is a chef, so she should have the vocabulary for flavors; let her use it. This specificity should extend to the cooking. Not "shroom risotto" but "the rice nearly gone to mush because they can't cook it precisely enough, but the shrooms are perfect, meaty and rich, and they add the last of their dried herbs, and somehow it tastes like something from a restaurant, like something from before." Not "Ahn's grandmother's recipe" but the actual steps, the actual smell of the kitchen where Ahn learned it, the actual way her grandmother's hands moved. ### Voice Variation Consider letting different chapters have slightly different voices based on what's happening. Chapter 1, written in the voice of a desperate person counting supplies, might be tighter, more clipped, more focused on numbers and facts. Chapter 5, written in the voice of someone planning a feast, might be looser, more expansive, more sensory. Chapter 7, written during an attack, might be fragmented, urgent, sentences breaking apart. This variation creates texture. It suggests a writer who is present in the material, feeling their way through it, rather than a system generating consistent prose to a specification. ### Unnecessary Scenes Consider adding scenes that don't serve the plot but serve the characters. A scene where Maren tries to remember her restaurant's signature dish and can only remember fragments—the smell of the kitchen, the sound of the tickets printing, the way the light came through the windows in the afternoon. A scene where Wes tells a story about before, something that has nothing to do with the Changed or the survival, just a memory that surfaces for no reason. A scene where the group plays a card game by candlelight, the game itself not important, the normalcy of playing together important. These scenes might slow the pacing, but they would also build the world and the characters in ways that plot-forward scenes can't. They would make the community feel real rather than functional. ### Moral Uncertainty Rather than having the characters accept the moral complexity of eating the Changed and moving on, let them grapple with it throughout. Maybe Wes never fully accepts it, and his reluctance is a presence in every meal. Maybe there's a moment where Maren watches a Changed from a distance and thinks about the fact that she eats what it leaves behind, and she feels something that isn't just hunger or relief. Maybe the question of whether the Changed are conscious or feel pain or remember being human comes up and no one has a good answer. This moral uncertainty might never resolve, and that's fine. Real moral uncertainty rarely resolves cleanly. ### Sensory Overload and Sensory Deprivation The cooking scenes should be sensory-rich, but the survival scenes could be sensory-poor. Let the contrast do work. When Maren is hunting for shrooms, she's hyperaware of every sound, every smell, every shadow—because those are the signs of Changed presence. When she's cooking, she's hyperaware of the sizzle, the steam, the way the light catches the steam, the taste on her tongue. The difference between these modes of awareness should feel like the difference between surviving and living. ### Imperfect Resolution The plan resolves most of its threads: the community merges, the attack is repelled, the survivors find a new normal. Consider what threads might remain imperfect. Maybe Patricia's group doesn't fully merge—they're allies now, but they're not family. Maybe Ahn's injury doesn't heal cleanly; she recovers enough to be functional but she's diminished, and the community has to adjust to that. Maybe the baby is healthy but cries too much, and the crying attracts Changed, and someone suggests they should leave, and there's a fight about it that doesn't fully resolve. ### The Personal Essay Impulse Consider moments where the prose breaks from third-person narrative to something more personal. Not first-person, necessarily, but a voice that sounds like Maren thinking to herself, reflecting on what's happened, not explaining it to the reader but working through it. These moments could be rare—just a sentence or two scattered through the story—but they would create intimacy. ### Bad Ideas That Work A human writer might include a scene or an idea that doesn't quite work but has energy. Maybe Maren tries to name the shrooms and comes up with something ridiculous, and the name sticks, and the group starts using it, and it's both funny and sad. Maybe there's a dish that Maren tries to make that fails completely, and they eat it anyway, and it's a bonding experience. Maybe Grandmother Ahn tells a story that doesn't make sense, or that contradicts something she said earlier, and no one corrects her because it's not important. These moments of imperfection make the story feel human. Perfect stories feel written. ### The Thing You Can't Explain Finally, consider what the story might include that doesn't have a clear purpose. A detail that Maren notices but doesn't act on. A sound that might or might not be the Changed. A feeling that passes through the community without anyone naming it. These unexplained elements create texture and depth; they suggest a world that extends beyond the story's boundaries. --- ## Synthesis: Moving Forward The existing plan is solid—it has good characters, a strong central premise, and a structure that allows both horror and warmth to breathe. But it could benefit from the critiques above in several specific ways. The character introductions should be more specific and less functional. The discovery arc should have more setbacks and complications. The "Feast" chapter might be restructured to let its elements breathe. The ending might hold onto uncertainty rather than resolving into warmth. Most importantly, the writing itself—when it comes time to write the chapters—should prioritize specificity over generality, voice over consistency, and emotion over efficiency. The goal isn't to execute the plan perfectly; it's to use the plan as a starting point and discover what the story actually wants to be as it unfolds.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention This piece aims to deliver a cozy-horror short story that earns its warmth through specificity, idiosyncrasy, and genuine emotional stakes—not through generic "dark but hopeful" beats. The central premise—eating the monsters that hunt you—is treated with the absurdity and dark humor it deserves, without over-explaining or softening its strangeness. The story prioritizes character texture over plot efficiency, allowing scenes to breathe and letting some threads remain unresolved. The prose will feel like it emerged from a particular mind with particular obsessions, not from a system optimizing for story structure. **The Protagonist**: Maren is a former chef, but she's not just a "chef character" for thematic convenience. She has specific memories, specific failures, specific dishes that haunt her. Her expertise manifests in small, concrete ways—not just "she knows food" but the way she holds a knife, the smell she associates with her grandmother's kitchen, the dish she can't quite remember how to make. She is competent but not heroic, hopeful but not naive. Her arc is about reclaiming purpose, but the purpose is messy and morally complicated. **The Tone Balance**: The story oscillates between registers rather than maintaining a consistent middle. Chapter 1 is tight and desperate; Chapter 5 is expansive and warm; Chapter 7 is fragmented and chaotic. This variation creates rhythm and suggests a writer present in the material. Dark humor appears in dialogue and observation, not in narrator commentary. The horror is real—the Changed are deadly, the world is broken—but the characters find moments of genuine comfort that feel earned rather than deployed. **The Moral Complexity**: The story doesn't resolve the ethics of eating the Changed. Wes never fully accepts it. Maren sometimes wonders if the growths are something the Changed are leaving deliberately. Grandmother Ahn eats without hesitation but sometimes cries while doing so. The ambiguity stays fuzzy, as it would in real life. **What to Avoid**: Over-explaining emotions (show, then trust the reader). Perfectly functional character introductions. Neatly resolved conflicts. Thematic statements. Consistent voice that never breaks pattern. Pacing that only moves the plot forward. **What to Embrace**: Specificity over generality. Unnecessary scenes that build character. Voice variations between chapters. Sensory richness in cooking scenes, sensory poverty in survival scenes. Imperfect resolutions. The thing that doesn't quite fit but has energy. --- # Chapter Planning **Chapter 1: "Basement Math" (approximately 1000 words)** - Opens with Maren counting supplies at 3 AM, unable to sleep. The math is grim but she keeps doing it anyway, a ritual of despair. - Introduce the basement as a space: the artificial light that never quite matches the sun, the smell of recycled air, the corner where Maren has started a tiny garden that isn't doing well. - The group is introduced not through description but through their presence: Delia checking on Maren because she heard her moving around; Wes's silhouette at the security monitor; the sound of Carlos and Yuki whispering in their corner; Grandmother Ahn's cold tea, forgotten again. - Maren's backstory emerges in fragments: the restaurant she co-owned, the partner who didn't make it, the menu she designed around local ingredients she can no longer find. - A small moment of specificity: Maren has been saving a single packet of saffron for no reason she can explain. She holds it sometimes, remembers the color, the expense, the dish she made it for. - Chapter ends with Maren finding a Changed spore trail closer to their living area than before. They've been getting closer. The math is about to get worse. **Chapter 2: "The Threads" (approximately 1000 words)** - Maren can't stop thinking about the spore trail. She tells herself it's paranoia, but she keeps going back to check. - She finds the growth in her garden—pale threads pushing through the soil where a spore must have settled. It shouldn't be growing here; the grow lights aren't right for fungus; the soil is too poor. - But it's growing anyway. Something about this basement, this particular patch of earth. - Maren's first instinct is to destroy it. She has a trowel in her hand. But she pauses. The color is strange—almost luminous. The smell is stranger still. - She tastes it. - The chapter doesn't play this for dramatic revelation. It plays it for the specific experience: the texture, the flavor that reminds her of something she can't name, the long moment after where she waits to die or transform. - Delia finds her sitting on the floor of the garden, holding a handful of fungus, crying. Not from fear. From relief. - Delia's reaction is practical horror. She doesn't understand. Maren can't explain. But there's a possibility here, and neither of them can look away. **Chapter 3: "Grandmother's Ghost" (approximately 1000 words)** - Maren has been harvesting the growth for three days, getting better at finding where the spores took root. She's becoming something between a farmer and a hunter. - The others are skeptical. Wes watches her with the expression of someone waiting to be proven right about the world. Carlos is curious but won't touch it. Yuki won't even look at it. - Grandmother Ahn is the first to help. She doesn't ask questions. She starts cleaning the growths, sorting them by size, teaching Maren a technique for trimming that Ahn learned from her own grandmother. - The technique has a name. Ahn tells her, but the name is in Korean and Maren can't reproduce it. Ahn demonstrates instead—the angle of the knife, the way you hold the fungus so it doesn't crumble. - A specific memory surfaces for Ahn: her grandmother's kitchen in Busan, the smell of dried shiitake, the way her grandmother hummed while she cooked. The memory is painful. Ahn doesn't finish the story. - They cook the first batch together. Simple preparation—just salt and heat, since that's all they have. The smell draws the others. Slowly, reluctantly, they come. - Wes is last. He takes one piece, holds it for a long time, eats it without looking at anyone. He doesn't say it's good. But he eats three more pieces. **Chapter 4: "The Language of Food" (approximately 1000 words)** - Two weeks of shrooms. Their bodies feel different—stronger, clearer. Their moods are better. But something else is changing. - Maren starts remembering her restaurant. Not just fragments—whole dishes. The way the light hit the dining room at 5 PM. The sound of the kitchen during a rush. Her partner's laugh. - She starts trying to recreate dishes. The results are imperfect: substitutions, missing ingredients, techniques that don't quite translate. But the attempt matters. - Carlos asks her why she bothers. They're surviving, not living. What's the point of making it pretty? - Maren doesn't have a good answer. But she keeps cooking anyway. - A dinner becomes a thing. Not a planned meal—just something that happens. Everyone is there. The candles are salvaged from an abandoned shop. The plates are mismatched. The food is simple. - Grandmother Ahn tells another story. Not about her grandmother this time—about a meal she had in 1987, in a small restaurant in Montreal, where she was the only Asian person in the room and the waiter kept calling her "ma'am" like he wasn't sure. The story doesn't have a point. It just exists, like the meal. - After dinner, Delia pulls Maren aside. The Changed have been moving differently. They're not just wandering anymore. They're patrolling. Something about the area has their attention. - Maren asks if it's them—the cooking, the warmth, the light. Delia doesn't know. Neither of them wants to stop anyway. **Chapter 5: "First We Eat" (approximately 1000 words)** - The scavengers find them. - Not through luck—through pattern. The group has been doing better than they should. Outsiders noticed. A woman named Patricia and two others from a larger settlement have been watching for days. - The confrontation is tense but not violent. Patricia's group is starving. They know Maren's group has something. They want to know what. - Maren takes them to the basement. Shows them the growths. Explains where they come from. Waits for the reaction. - Patricia doesn't believe her. She's heard the stories—people who eat the Changed go crazy, turn, die. It's not food. It's poison. - Maren cooks for her. Doesn't argue. Just cooks. - Patricia eats. The silence after is longer than usual. When she looks up, her eyes are wet. - Her group has been eating rats and cardboard and whatever they could find. She forgot food could taste like this. She forgot that eating could feel like something other than survival. - The merger is not smooth. Patricia's people are wary. Wes is hostile. There isn't enough space. There aren't enough supplies. But Maren keeps cooking, and slowly, the meals become the meeting point. - A specific detail: Patricia's group brought a child, maybe seven years old. The child is shy at first, hides behind Patricia's legs. By the end of the chapter, she's helping Maren wash the fungus, asking questions about the different types, their colors, their names. **Chapter 6: "The Growers" (approximately 1000 words)** - The community has grown. The basement is crowded. The shroom harvest isn't enough anymore. - Maren has to go further out to find new growth sites. The Changed are thicker in those areas. The risk is higher. - During one harvest, she sees something that makes her stop. - A Changed is standing at the edge of a clearing. Not moving. Not hunting. Just... standing. And around its feet, the growth is thicker than Maren has ever seen. A carpet of pale threads, reaching toward the Changed like they reach toward the light. - The Changed doesn't attack. Doesn't even acknowledge her. It's like she's not there. - Maren waits for it to move. It doesn't. She harvests as much as she can carry and runs. - She doesn't tell anyone. Not yet. - Back at the basement, she studies the growth more carefully. The patterns. The way it appears where the Changed congregate. The way the Changed seem to leave trails of spore that become food. - A hypothesis forms. She doesn't like it. - That night, she dreams of her restaurant. The dining room is full of Changed. They're sitting at the tables, holding menus, waiting to order. She's behind the counter, terrified, but also—embarrassed. She doesn't have enough shrooms. She can't feed them all. - She wakes up sweating. The kitchen is empty. Outside, the Changed are moving, their patterns strange and deliberate. She watches them for an hour, trying to see what they're doing. She can't. **Chapter 7: "The Long Night" (approximately 1000 words)** - The attack comes in the middle of the night. - Not the usual breach—something bigger. Something organized. They come from all sides at once, and it's clear they know where everyone sleeps. - The fight is chaos. There's no heroism, just terror and desperation. Carlos is bleeding from his arm. Yuki is screaming. Patricia is firing until she runs out of ammunition. - In the middle of it, Grandmother Ahn is hit. No one sees how. One moment she's there, the next she's on the ground, and there's a Changed on top of her, and then there isn't—Wes is there, somehow, dragging it off, and there's so much blood. - The Changed don't retreat so much as stop. It's not clear why. One moment they're pressing in, the next they're pulling back, disappearing into the dark like they were never there. - Someone is crying. It's the child. She's standing in the middle of the room, holding a fistful of shrooms, crying. She was supposed to be hiding. She was supposed to be safe. - Ahn is alive but barely. Delia is working on her, hands shaking, using supplies they don't have to spare. - The chapter ends in the aftermath. People are wounded. The basement is damaged. And Ahn is alive, but no one knows for how long, and there's no medicine, no help, no way out. - Maren sits next to Ahn's sleeping form. Holds her cold tea cup, forgotten again. Doesn't know what to do. **Chapter 8: "Call Everyone to Eat" (approximately 1000 words)** - Morning. Ahn is still alive. - The community is broken and whole at the same time. They take inventory: wounded but alive, supplies damaged but not gone, the child asleep in a corner, unhurt. - Patricia's group stays. Not because they've been asked, but because they know they can't make it alone. They merge, awkwardly, painfully, into one community. - Maren cooks breakfast. Not a feast—just what they have. The shrooms, some of the last rice, the salvaged vegetables from her dying garden. She cooks until her arms ache. - The child wakes up. Finds Maren in the kitchen. Doesn't say anything—just stands close, watching, learning. - "Call everyone to eat," Maren says. The child runs off. - A moment alone. Maren tastes the food. It's good. It might be the last good meal they have, or one of many. She doesn't know. She tastes it anyway. - The community gathers. Not around a table—there aren't enough chairs—but in the space where they eat, where they've always eaten. The light is wrong. The air smells like blood and burnt coffee and shrooms cooking. - Ahn is there. propped up, pale, alive. She holds the cup of tea that someone made for her. It will get cold. She won't drink it. - The meal starts. No one says anything profound. There's no toast, no speech, no moment of realization. Just eating. Quiet, tired, grateful eating. - Outside, the Changed are moving. Their patterns are strange. Maren watches them through the crack in the door. They don't seem interested in the basement. They seem to be... going somewhere. - Maybe they're cultivating something. Maybe they're growing food for something else. Maybe they know something Maren doesn't. - She doesn't know. She'll never know. - The child tugs at her sleeve. Asks a question about the shrooms. Maren answers. The child listens, serious, memorizing. - The meal continues. The sun moves across the floor. Somewhere outside, the Changed keep moving. - Not a happy ending. Not a sad one. Just a morning. Just food. Just the stubborn act of eating together in a world that wants them dead. - The last line: Maren clears her throat. Calls for everyone to try the next dish. Her voice is hoarse. It carries anyway. --- # Quick Reference: Emotional Arc | Chapter | Dominant Tone | Key Development | |---------|---------------|-----------------| | 1 | Quiet despair | Setting stakes, introducing the space and people | | 2 | Frightened possibility | Discovery, first taste, seeds of hope | | 3 | Cautious collaboration | First successful meal, Ahn's generational memory | | 4 | Fragile joy | Routine emerges, community forms around food | | 5 | Hopeful tension | Outside contact, merger, new dynamics | | 6 | Growing unease | Changed behavior, Maren's discovery, dreams | | 7 | Terror and aftermath | Attack, injury, cost of survival | | 8 | Quiet determination | Morning after, community holds, uncertainty remains |
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Maren Maren was thirty-four years old when the world ended, and thirty-three when she opened her restaurant. The numbers matter to her—they're the kind of detail she used to include on the menu, a small story attached to each dish. She keeps a mental menu still, updating it with what they find, what they kill, what grows in the basement. It's a compulsion. She can't stop herself. Before the Changed, she co-owned a farm-to-table restaurant called Root & Branch in a gentrifying neighborhood that used to be a manufacturing district. She designed the menu around local ingredients—whatever farmers within a hundred miles could provide. She specialized in fermentation, the long slow patient work of turning things into other things. Her restaurant had a kombucha program. People wrote about it. She still remembers the review that called her "a chef who understands that food is transformation." She thought it was pretentious then. She thinks about it constantly now. Her partner was named David. He handled the business side—accounting, ordering, the terrible paperwork of running a restaurant. He was better at math than she was, which is why she was counting supplies when the infection hit, and why she was the one who noticed the numbers going wrong. David didn't make it. She doesn't talk about how. She has a theory that he turned into one of the Changed on the third day, that she watched it happen and couldn't stop it. But she wasn't really there. She might have been somewhere else. Memory is unreliable now. Maren's idiosyncrasies are specific and sometimes obsessive. She carries a chef's knife that belonged to her grandmother—Japanese steel, uncomfortable to hold for long, perfect balance. She sharpens it even when it doesn't need it, the ritual of it. She has a packet of saffron that she saved from the restaurant's last order, and she takes it out sometimes just to hold it, to remember the color. She doesn't know what she'll do with it. She'll probably never use it. The packet is a relic. She's fastidious in ways that annoy the others. She washes her hands more than necessary. She organizes the supplies by type and expiration, even though expiration dates are meaningless now. She can't stop herself from lining up the canned goods, alphabetized by content. It's not OCD, exactly. It's the only control she has left. Her flaws are real. She can be dismissive when she's focused, not meaning to be but failing to notice other people entirely. She's competitive about stupid things—her shroom dishes, her harvest numbers, as if survival is a competition she can win. She carries guilt about David that she doesn't examine, because examination would require time she doesn't have and emotions she's afraid of. She sometimes resents the group for needing her, even though feeding people is the only thing she knows how to do. **Physicality**: Maren moves like someone who's spent years in a kitchen—efficient, economical, her hands always doing something even when she's standing still. She's lost weight since the apocalypse began, and her cheekbones are sharper than they used to be. She keeps her hair short, cut with the kitchen scissors when it gets too long, because she doesn't have the patience for anything else. Her hands are calloused and nicked from knife work. She has a small burn scar on her left forearm from a pan she grabbed too quickly; she got it three weeks before the Changed appeared and thinks about it constantly because it was the last injury she got from cooking for pleasure. She wears an apron that she salvaged from the restaurant, even though it's falling apart, even though the others think she's being sentimental. She doesn't correct them. **Motives and Allegiances**: Maren's primary allegiance is to the group that kept her alive, but her deeper motive is to feed people. She can't separate the two. She believes—fervently, irrationally—that if she can cook for someone, she's giving them something that matters. It's not just nutrition. It's proof that the world still contains pleasure, that they're still human. This belief drives her to take risks, to push the boundaries of what's safe, to keep cooking even when resources are scarce. Her relationships are complicated: she trusts Delia but resents being managed; she respects Wes even though he makes her angry; she adores Ahn and is terrified of losing her. She doesn't have a romantic interest and the story won't give her one—this isn't that kind of story. **Voice experiments**: - Internal monologue: "The saffron packet. She could use it for rice, stretch the flavor, make something that tastes like before. But before is gone. The saffron is a relic, not a resource. She'll never use it. She'll carry it until she dies, and someone will find it in her pocket and wonder what it was for." - Dialogue: "Everyone's going to eat. I don't care if it's shrooms and rainwater and whatever scraps we have left. We're sitting down together. That's what food is for." --- # Delia Delia was an ICU nurse for twelve years before the Changed appeared. She held dying people's hands. She watched families say goodbye through glass windows during COVID. She was good at her job because she learned to separate herself from the horror—kindly, professionally, but absolutely. She became the person who made decisions when others couldn't. Now she makes all the decisions. Not because she wanted to, but because someone had to, and the others kept looking at her like she knew what to do. She doesn't know what to do. She's making it up as she goes, and she's terrified that someday her luck will run out. She grew up in a military family—her father was a colonel, her mother a civilian contractor. They moved every two years. She learned early how to fit in anywhere and belong nowhere. She's adaptable to the point of emptiness, which is why she became a nurse, which is why she became a leader. She knows how to assess a situation, identify the priorities, delegate the work. She doesn't know how to do anything else. Her idiosyncrasies are quieter than Maren's. She has a habit of checking pulses when she's anxious—her own, other people's. She doesn't realize she's doing it until someone points it out, and then she's embarrassed for days. She keeps a notepad with her at all times, even though there's no paper to spare, even though she's been writing in pencil until there's nothing left but eraser. The notepad is a prop, a security blanket. She looks at it when she's thinking, pretends to write things down. It makes her feel like she has a plan. Her flaws are the flaws of exhaustion. She snaps at people she loves. She makes decisions too quickly and then can't sleep wondering if she was wrong. She sometimes resents the group for needing her, even though she's the one who positioned herself as indispensable. She had a sister in another city who probably died during the first wave, and Delia hasn't grieved because she can't afford to. **Physicality**: Delia moves like someone who's been on her feet for too long—efficient, purposeful, no wasted motion. She's the kind of person who walks into a room and immediately identifies the exits, the medical supplies, the people who look unwell. She has tired eyes that used to be described as kind. Her hair is pulled back in a practical ponytail, graying at the temples. She wears layers of clothing even when it's warm, because she learned to dress for every emergency. She has a scar on her palm from a broken vial during a code—something that happened years ago, before the Changed, before everything. She holds her hands behind her back when she's talking to the group, a posture she adopted unconsciously to keep from fidgeting. **Motives and Allegiances**: Delia's primary motive is keeping people alive. Not just her group—anybody she can help. This puts her in conflict with Wes sometimes, who believes in hoarding resources and protecting their position. She's the moral center of the group in a way she never wanted to be, the one who has to make calls about who gets what, who gets treated, who gets left behind. Her relationships are rooted in duty: she protects Maren because Maren is essential, she tolerates Wes because he's useful, she loves Ahn like a mother she never had. She doesn't have romantic interests either; she's too tired. **Voice experiments**: - Internal monologue: "The math. She was always better at math than Maren, which is why she was counting when the numbers started going wrong. Twelve patients in ICU. Twelve. And then the Changed came through the windows, and there were more of them than there were of us, and someone was screaming, and she just—kept counting. It's all she knows how to do." - Dialogue: "We're not leaving anyone. I don't care if they're slowed down, I don't care if they're a liability. We leave someone behind, we're not the kind of people who survive. And I refuse to be that kind of person." --- # Wes Wes was a military contractor. He doesn't like to talk about what he did, exactly—something with acronyms, something overseas, something that paid well and left him with skills he didn't ask for. He was between contracts when the Changed appeared, staying in a rental apartment, wondering what he was going to do with his life. The answer turned out to be: survive. He's the group's sentry, their tactical mind, the one who knows how to fortify and defend. He's good at it because he's trained for violence. The Changed don't scare him the way they scare other people; they're just another threat to neutralize. What scares him is the other survivors—the desperate, the cunning, the ones who will do anything to live. He's seen what people become when survival is the only goal. He doesn't want to become that. He's not sure he hasn't already. His idiosyncrasies are military-adjacent. He cleans his weapon even when it doesn't need cleaning. He speaks in radio call signs sometimes, catches himself, stops. He has a habit of checking the locks and exits in any building he enters, and he can't turn it off. He carries a notebook with hand-drawn maps of the city—places he's scouted, routes he's walked, dangers he's catalogued. The maps are meticulous, almost beautiful. He's not artistic in any other way.
